39405216.review:
My favorite round of this game:

- Spawned as mercenary, in charge of just keeping one character alive. No faction allegiance.
- Caring about my life, I inform the king of my class and contract. It's a popular policy to kill any confirmed neutral players in the hopes of catching a killer.
- Guarded my contract for a bit, before becoming the third member of the Unseen, the "evil" faction. Now I guard them at night.
- Mastermind felt great about getting a Sorceror killed, despite the fact that Sorcerors are the one neutral killer class that can't kill evil characters. Our 45 seconds of nightly privacy is not long enough for this discussion.
- After a few nights of guarding our assassin, and watching the Blue Dragon accuse each other, the King dies, and so does my original contract.
- I keep up the facade, claiming I need a new contract.  My Mastermind "accepts" ;)
- BUT then my Mastermind accidentally clicks to nominate himself for King, (Another bad MM move) and is found out as evil pretty quickly. Fortunately, nobody follows up about who I chose as my contract.
- There are six players left: me, our assassin, and 4 of the Blue Dragon. I step forward to become King after our former Mastermind is executed. One of the enemies knows our assassin visited someone who died last night. I have to execute him to blend in. I *thought* I could pardon him using a king ability, but I guess it wasn't available my first day.
- The game is still going which means there's still an evil character about. (It's me)
- The four opponents remaining accuse each other, thinking a mastermind wouldn't become King, because their recruitment ability is too valuable. They think the MM is still out there, and can't know he was the previous king.
- Our assassin poisoned one of the four BD before he died, and the poison takes effect the next night. Only 3 remain. I have to kill 2, but the only way to do that is voting on execution.
- One execution goes smoothly. More confusion among my "subjects".
- Not used to being King, I make another mistake and use an ability to make an accusation count as 2 votes, locking me out of my ability to immediately execute or pardon someone on the stand. I start a trial for one of the remaining.
- He presents convincing logs.
- The other BD and I lock in our votes. If he pardons, there's no execution, and they'll no doubt turn on me soon.
- The other BD rescinds their vote and chats "This is all too confusing!" choosing to trust his King.
- He chose wrong.
- By my will alone, I, the Evil King, execute his last ally and extinguish all hope for the Blue Dragon.
- The Unseen win.

10/10. Would bumble my way through murder and incompetent leadership to become a tyrant again.

Other highlights:
- One time I got raised from the dead late in the game to to do some secret guarding and murder at night. I took a shot in the dark and killed the remaining evil player the same night he killed the other two survivors. Everyone died and it was beautiful!
- One time there was a toxic player (not a common problem I've seen. I think the devs take reports seriously) and I openly asked the evil faction to kill him. They did the same night. And then the night before they won, they recruited me and let me share in their victory! Thanks, guys!


Seriously though, this game has a bit of a steep learning curve as you learn not only each class's abilities, but also the "etiquette" of the chat and logs. I had some embarassing early sessions, but it's completely worth it for the dynamic stories like the ones above, and players have generally been good sports. Mostly, the worst the worst I've heard is "that was a bad [class] play", which, yeah, usually was.

If I can suggest an improvement, give a little more visual feedback when YOU are getting accused during the day. Maybe change the color of that text from yellow to red, so you at least know damn sure to get your logs ready.

39402011.review: Super in-depth, fun experience.  My favorite game of 2017 hands down.

39399946.review:
If you've played Town of Salem, it won't take you long to understand the game.  Most of the classic roles are here are here with a new twist.  Everyone has a night role for investigation or support.  The main difference here is that everyone but the King, most neutrals and the Prince (AKA jailer)  can be converted to evil during the night.  the factions are the Blue Dragon, Neutrals, the Cult and the Unseen, each bring a different (or they try to) playstyle.

[h1] Pros	[/h1]
[list]
    [*]"Time of Death labels"
    [*]Extensive Codex
    [*]Interesting Neutral Killers
    [*]Death Knight Mechanics
[/list]

[h1] Pros	Expanded[/h1]
Time of Death labels-Such a simple bit of UI really helps keeping track of events.

Always something to do-  No matter what role you have, you will have something to do at night.  That beats the heck out of the Medium and survivor in ToS.

Day abilities-  While not fully balanced yet, they do add some spice into the chats.

Neutral Killer- The Possessor has the most unique ability to "jump bodies"  that adds tension to the whole game.  However if enough people start using a "Whisper "Blankety Blank" until I'm posessed" Meta that could change. 

Death Knights-Instead of reviving someone, you get to make them a Death Knight.  An undead avenger that watches over the Blue Dragons and attacks 1 player and kills them if they are evil.  This stops people from having "Confirmed good roles" that utterly kill evil factions.

[h1] Cons List	[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Tiny Community.
    [*]No other modes.
    [*]Underpowered "Good" Roles.
    [*]Toxic Community.
    [*]Games are binary wins or losses.
    [*]Codex missing key features
    [*]No stats or achievements
[/list]

[h1]  Cons Expanded	[/h1]
Neuts out!-  Are you a neutral role?  Well if the king find you 9/10 times you are executed for existing.  The only reason to not kill them is the very outside chance there is a fool.  When a fool is executed Days 1-3, you can't even vote anyone up for 2 days!  
It doesn't help that any revealed Neutrals are forced to work with the BDs if they want to survive.

Salty losers-  You can carry the Blue Dragons to victory and then lose because you are converted one night before the games ends.  This makes it easy to be angry at the loss of gold and prestige at your efforts.

The King role-  This role can be 1/3 different factions.  Good, Evil or Neutral.  However all of them play the exact same!  Same abilities and same results.  If you don't find someone by Day 5 everyone cries "EXE THE EVIL KING!".  There have been multiple reworks, but none of them solve this problem.  Worse yet, New kings that get elected lose all ability to investigation abilities.

The "Diversity" Update.  So, you put back in another powerless role, the Noble, then you add an update so that you "Don't play the same role twice."  I've tested this and in over 4 hours of gameplay it put me in the exact same role 4 times! To recap why they tried to fix this, I had played over 40 hours and NEVER had 3 specific roles even once!  The Roles structure is BS!

Basic information hidden-  I scoured the Codex and all roles and it was only after HOURS of play that I learned that there can be only 2 of each role.  This is mentioned only ONCE in the online Wiki.  The dev expects us all to use their "Discord" for help.  NO THANK YOU!

Trash Unprovable Roles-  In ToS you have only a few real roles that have no way to confirm themselves.  In here you have 5+.  The Court Wizard, The Hunter (90% of the time), the Physician, the Princess and the Knight.  Yes, as the knight, you could put out a death note saying Knightman wuz here!  Big problem is that details on a death are hidden, DNs are mostly ignored.  Worse yet if the evil factions believe the note, you get converted.

The "Occupy roles"-  In town of salem you'd call this Roleblocking.  Unlike in ToS there are two, and each time there are noobs that will try to play them as "investigative roles".  This leads to them exposing other BD roles and the prince more than any evil roles.  I'm pretty sure this stems from frustration at having a menial passive role.  The Drunk can either Occupy them, or Happy hour people.  Removing ALL immunities and 100% stopping their target in their tracks.  The problem is, this doesn't kill them without either a hunter, or a Knight working with them.

"Killing roles-  The prince is the most powerful role in the game bar none.  The problem is that when he dies Night 1 or 2 evils win.  Period.  No matter what other roles are in the game, I have NEVER seen evils lose when prince dies N1 and only Disconnected (or incredibly unprepared) players make can overturn this rule of thumb.  However this can also be said for the Neutral Killer.  If the NK dies early the evil faction is badly outnumbered.  Without multiple deaths per night, they are hunted down and killed in quick order.

No seasons, stats or achievements- Yes, we all hate unreasonable grinding.  However, stats would stop people from leaving, a problem that even giving more gold for wins hasn't solved.  Reports literally do nothing, they are unprovable and often jut a bunch of trolls trying to spread malice.  Worse yet, any achievements WOULD give new players an idea of what a class can and should do.

[h1] Summary	[/h1]

It's better than ToS the Coven, but that's about it.  You will get bored until it updates, and you will be forced into playing the same roles over and over.  Even when it does update, the bugs, crashes and ignorant trolls will never disappear from this game.  The only reason to get this game would be either to do social experiments (just use a chat room, those are free) or to learn what NOT to do when creating a mafia style game.  I wish I could like it, but the number of times one player can make a difference are buried by mountains of disappointments, and frustrating hordes of idiots chanting "EZ game".

39345777.review:
I have to recommend this game, as I have enjoyed many, many hours since having bought it this last winter (2017). The game itself seems to be balanced well enough and is still being carefully maintained by the devs - at least by all appearances, as I've witnessed re-introduction of playable classes and tweaking of numbers even in the short time I have owned the game.

The only real trouble this game is plagued with is the human condition. There are some people that believe themselves to be godlike geniuses and they will chew you out without hesitation when they predict something and no one else sees it. There are some people that will get salty beyond the point of hilarity, past the threshold of just being a (donkey) and I can't say I'd miss them if they just quit playing altogether.

You will find games with intelligent and/or respectful and/or cheerful players. Sometimes you only get a little of one, rarely you'll get a good measure of all. You will find some that respect new players and give them room for mistakes, and you will find some that will blame you just for trying to enter the community. The latter are poisonous and need to adjust their attitudes or leave.

So buy the game if you've got the stomach and/or thick skin for dealing with sore losers and self-appointed geniuses. You will encounter them, no doubt. The game itself, lying beneath, is worth it. It's fun. But if you can't deal with jerks, you may find your experience soiled every other game. There are always people cussing each other out. There are always idiots. Thankfully, I can get past it. I don't blame you if you can't.

Sounds negative, I know, I know... I mean, it's hard to paint toxic players in a good light, true. Many negative reviews are based heavily on experiences with the community. But I'm here to tell you: the game itself is fun (after you conquer the admittedly steep learning curve) and would admittedly improve with a friendlier player base, but it's still fun. It's satisfying to catch others in their lies - tremendously more satisfying to carry yourself on a bed of lies all the way to victory. I have enjoyed playing both sides of the game, enjoyed playing the neutral roles (even though they are often mistrusted by default). I have been blamed and whined at and I think I've probably been threatened with reports (or been reported, who knows) by players that think the definition of "throwing a game" is "not winning." But you know what? Those players can stuff it. They won't steal the joyous thrill I get from trying to figure everyone out every match.

It's fun, win or lose. And I get frustrated with a lot of those difficult singleplayer romps out there (Dark Souls and the like). This game is good for cooling off, as I enjoy watching everything unfold (I even have some guilty pleasure in watching the idiots that chew each other out, if I'm honest).

If I sound crazy to you, you'll probably hate this game. Ultimately, enjoyment can only be measured on a personal level. If I sound reasonable to you, give it a go.

39326973.review: It's like Mafia or Town of Salem, but actually fun

39298534.review: Throne of Lies well satisfies fans of board-games and multiplayer puzzles, especially if you've had fun with games like "Secret Hitler," or "Werewolf." Where it lacks in visual quality (likely most comparable to a Runescape style) it makes up for in evolving strategy. Players have limited options for how they control their characters, and thus mainly get along by interacting through instant messaging with the other players--meaning that victory or defeat will largely come down to how you make friends and enemies through the twenty minutes you spend with everyone. Due to the low amount of total players each day, it's possible you'll create lasting friendships or rivalries with other fans. Unfortunately, the game does not appeal well to a cooperative environment, as friends aren't meant to share information, and will have to remain quiet with each other to observe the rules. The amount of time you'll receive from Throne of Lies will vary based on your imagination and attraction to the roleplay, but for such a simple game, it can really impress.

39293903.review:
Awesome game! Litterally the best and closest thing you'll get to an authentic detective game. Before I go into pros and cons, let me say that this game is better version of Town of Salem with a far more amusing and intellectual community. This is not some copy of Town of Salem, just a superior game within the small genre. On that note lets start with the cons.

Cons:
Overplayed Class- This is honestly my most hated one! Although I love every class usually it eat at me that I'm Court Wizard and Psychic in succession after one another. So further improvement on the Algorithm is needed.

Graphics- The graphics are honestly meh, but you get used to it after your 3rd match or so. 

No Ranked- Bummer for me as I love making my games a bit more competitive. If they could give me ranked, I would spend even more hours on the game. This obviously doesn't matter to most. 

Pros:
Loads of Classes- There are so many clases yielding to some diverse games. This is why the con annoys me so much. But my goodness I could play for hours if I never get a class repeat. All of them have their strengths. Some would say about 4 of them are dumb, but 4 out of 25+ are still some good odds.

Fun Community- From the RP'ers to the meme'ers all of them make this game a joy to play. You once in a blue mind find a game thrower, but every game has its share of toxic people. That being said, for a game that is litterally about talking, you don't get any true animosity in spite of funny/wrong accusations or poor deductions.

Customizations- The game could certainly use more character avatars and weapons, but they have a plethora already. You could swipe your card to unlock themn all, but its honestly no need. You get money quickly, and it gives you more of a reason to play.

Conversions- This honestly may be the reason why systematically I like Throne of Lies over Town of Salem is because you just never know who got converted. So everyone is suspect until certain variables are met.

Conclusion:
I'll stop here as I could go on longer, but theres no need. You really need to play this for yourself to understand why its so good. If you're like me and are completely knew to this type of game, go play Town of Salem to see if you like the genre. If you conclude that you like the genre then PLEASE buy this game, its so much better with true deductions instead of random accusation kills in Town of Salem.

39040866.review:
You play as either a faction, or a neutral. Blue Dragon are the "good" guys and the unseen/cult are the "bad" guys. The good guys have to kill the bad guys to win, and vice versa for the bad guys. There are also a number of "neutral" roles that can win withe either side (they're neutral). Also, nobody knows who is what at the start of the game. It's you and your teams job to find out who is what using your abilities and information from other players.

If you wan't to do well, you will need a keen eye and recognise who could be lying and who might be converted to the bad guys. If you're a bad guy, you'll need to know who to kill, convert or annoy with your abilities. If you're a neutral, you'll need to learn how to not die (for the most part).

There are a number of roles in the game, and most (all?) of them have "night abilities". For example, the sheriff can go to one players house each night and see if they are part of the enemy faction. The knight can guard a player and kill anyone who attacks them. Some classes, have day abilities. The assasin, can poison a player during the day. The Butler can poison the king, the alchemist can make himself night immune for one night.

The game is fun with infinite replay value as no two games are the same. You could have a hundred hours and the closest you could get to that would be "similar things happened at one or two points", but nothing more.

If you have played games like Town of Salem, this is a definite upgrade in terms of graphics and gameplay, with the only drawback being there is no way to up your chances of getting a certain role.

Speaking of ToS, most of the roles are similar, but do have differences. The hunter is a vig/vet combo, the princess is like the investigator but seens class types, and not the class (support/social Vs. Physician/Alchemist/Psy etc), the sheriff is (basically) the sheriff. Evil can recruit people and can even kill twice in one night. The king is similar to the mayor, however he can execute regardless of the votes. there is a neutral healing class called the alchemist that can attack twice, make themselves immune and heal. There is a reaper (NK), when they kill a player, they appear as alive the next day however cannot talk.

Again, most of the classes follow the same theme as ToS, but mostly have different mechanics.

This game will take *at least* a good few hours at least to pick up, and thousands to master.

This game is exactly what it says on the tin. It's a fairly complex Werewolf-style game of deceit. There are a lot of classes and abilities to keep track of, and the online community has some issues. People in public games communicate mostly in rapid-fire notation, so don't expect to survive those games very long if you can't learn the lingo. If you have a large group of friends to play with, you probably don't have to care too much about that.

All in all, a strong first showing from the developer. If you like this kind of game, you'll probably like this one. Eventually. Once you figure everything out.

38950434.review:
Throne of Lies is a team-based social deduction game in the same vein as other games such as Werewolf, Mafia, Town of Salem, etc. What sets it apart from the pack is depth. If Town of Salem is a shallow pond, then Throne of Lies is a very deep lake. There are no "useless" roles. Each role has at least 2 (up to 5 or 6) special abilities, which leads to a very confusing 3 to 6 hours of gameplay until you start memorizing each class and how they all fit together. Even now, at 25 hours of game time, I'm still learning new things. The in-game GUI is very easy to navigate and alot of the drudgery of other such games is handled automatically (preformatted nightly logs, etc.).

Summary: If you like social deduction games, then you'll love Throne. It's definitely worth a buy, but be prepared for a steep learning curve initially. Power through that and you'll be rewarded with a richer social deduction experience than you're used to.

38949146.review:
So I have been playing a lot of mafia-type games for the past year (Town of Salem, Throne of Lies, Mindnight, Camp Cadaver), and no matter how much I try to branch out, I always seem to return to ToL

Now, before we continue with this review, I will admit that I've ditched this game for weeks on end more than once. Does that mean that I hate it and that secretly I am a masochist? Could be- but the honest answer would be no- I do not hate this game.

Onto the actual review- the reason why I keep on returning to this game is because it's complex, it's beautiful, and it exposes all of humanity's good and bad traits. From truly careful and masterful ploys to earn your trust, to the most bitter and angry of words- Throne of Lies has it all. You're gonna all say "This is true for all social deduction games- what makes this one different?" Well, frankly, it's the sheer amount of classes, abilities, factions. This is the only game that I know of, that allows conversions (forcing people to join your faction), which can easily make a winning faction loose in a single night.

On another note that still relates to why I love this game is the developers and moderators- seldom have I seen devs so dedicated to listening (or reading as it were) to player feedback, and being extremely fast to respond to people's issues. If you report a player for a misdemeanor of some effect, you can rest assured that the mods will DEFINITELY take action.

Now, onto the not so pleasant things- the community can be incredibly toxic- to the point where you rage-quit and uninstall the game, only to re-install it again the next day.
Another issue is the fact that due to constant player demands, you will discover that a lot of classes suffer from endless changes, to the point of being removed (priest, soulcatcher and noble come to mind), which means that if you stay away from the game for two weeks, you might end up in a scenario where you do not know what's happening around you, because all of your abilities are changed to the core. 
A final gripe that does not personally affect me, but non-the-less IS important, is that the game is NOT friendly to new players. There are too many mechanics to learn, too many classes and factions to figure our, and no real way to seperate new players from the experienced ones. While there is supposed to be a way to prevent new players from recieving certain roles (like King, Prince, or participation in Cult games), this often seems to not be the case, as I've seen on multiple occasions first-time players get King (which can be part of 3 different factions, thus make the way to achieve victory very different), which not only guarantees loss for them, but also all players that are part of their faction.


TL,DR: The game is awesome- graphics are entertaining, the sheer amount of classes will ensure that you'll always have something new to see or learn, and it's one of the most complicated social deduction games (I love that) that I've ever played. The developers truly love their playerbase, and they will always listen to your issues. With that being said, be sure to come prepared with your thickest skin and absolute disregard for people's opinions, otherwise this game will eat you and spit you out severely damaged. Also, if you're overall new to the "social deduction games" genre, be sure to watch a few videos, read up the basics on the Wiki a bit before starting up your first game- no one is gonna hold your hand while you learn the ropes.

Good luck and I hope to meet you in the throne room that is full of liars!

P.S.: English is NOT my native language- feel free to mock me for any grammar mistakes that you encounter!

38921438.review:
A few friends asked me if they should get this game, so I'm writing a review to help anyone out.
Things to note:
 - I have had this game less than a week but I have played ~20 hours
 - I might have like a thousand hours in Town of Salem, so I just like this type of game


Pros:
 + in a game where other players directly impact your experience, the community takes this game seriously and works very hard. 
  ( +/- unlike in town of salem, this means that most people don't play "characters" and instead focus on serious dialogues)
 + you can play it while doing something else (like, i read something during the downtime) or you can focus on it
 + the game is very balanced so you don't have to worry about a certain faction always winning
 + you can play an active role even when dead (by gaining gold for predicting who will be executed or killed at night)
 + each new game is challenging and different from the one before
 + completely new roles from Town of Salem, so everything is fresh and interesting

Cons:
 - the community can have a toxic view of the norm of a game. logs play too important of a role
 - sometimes you can get the same class multiple times and that can get annoying
 - there's a bit of a steep learning curve at first, with so many new roles.
  ( + people are helpful and you are always learning new things)
 - visuals could use a lot of improvement. it feels like i'm playing 2003 runescape.
  ( + they're more interesting than town of salem and are easy to get used to. plus, there are nice animations)
 - the lobbies can be filled with people you've played games with before. community is not very large.
 - music can get a little stale after a while

I could easily play this game for hundreds of hours. It challenges you as much as you want it to. If you want to buy it, then I will be there to play it with you. 
Is it worth playing when you could play Town of Salem for free? I would say so, especially if you have grown tired of ToS. These devs care more about this game. I like playing it.

38849490.review:
Throne of Lies is a Mafia-style game. There are the usual Good, Evil, and Neutral classes; each with their own objectives and abilities.

In terms of gameplay, the game is good. There is a large amount of replay value with over 30+ classes and 2 different Evil factions. The King class guides players as the central authority. And most Good classes can be converted by special Evil classes into Evil classes. Hence, attention to detail is required to win as the Good faction.

In terms of story, there is practically none. 

In terms of graphics, the game is... lacking. The UI is not very beautiful and the player models and animations are sloppy and unrefined.

In terms of music, the game is good. Most classes have unqiue sound bites and the general score is pleasent to listen to.

In terms of networking, the game is variable. Since the game is preer to peer, connectivity depends on the host.

This game is a crap-ton of fun. I never actually gotten around to playing Town of Salem, because I wasn't really into the overall theme of it, but boi Throne of Lies has medieval politics and it fits so well with the game play.  
 
When you first get into the game, you'll spend probably a good 30 minutes in a round typically, it doesn't feel like 30 minutes at all. Some games go faster, some are slower. For me the average game is around 30 minutes give or take. You'll be a bit confused at first, but it's okay, you'll get a hang of it. The best thing I can suggest to new players is to join the discord, they actually link it on the store page. The people there are extremely helpful.  
 
The people you get in Throne of Lies is different, sometimes you get toxic players that do stupid things in the game. Usually toxic players try to kill off neutrals, which sucks whenever you're a neutral player yourself. It's not every game this happens though, and I have to admit, the community is rather hard on you in the game whenever you're a new player. It's okay, just tell them you're a new player in the dead chat and if someone is around, they will probably explain some things to you. I seriously recommend joining the discord of any help though.  
 
All in all, Throne of Lies is pretty freaking fun. I've had the game for a couple of days now and I feel like with each game I'm learning more and more about the roles I get and how to play better. This game is super easy to get lost in.

I never got into the "social game" genre because I think people are idiots and it turned me off to be forced to work with randoms each game. But... alas.. I tried it. The game has a lot of fail safes to prevent trolls and friends working together to really ruin the game.So I was pleased with that for sure.
But the game itself, it took a little while to understand. After the first few games I wasn't sure how much enjoyment I'd get.  There are so many classes to learn their skills and the "rules" about identifying what the objective is each game and what classes are going to show up. Then I was playing for 6 hours at a time because it became SO interesting!
I never thought I'd have so much fun dieing in a game and spectating to the end to see all the plot twists and turns that develop, some of my own doing that don't reveal themselves until days after my own death. It scratches some itch I didn't know I had that is a casual entertaining game, but also very competitive in nature itself.

38787462.review:
Сегодня у нас на операционном столе "3D Town of Salem" 

Итак, до начала самого обзора нам нужно прояснить две вещи:
1) Игра основана на всем известной Мафии, если вам она противна, то и ТоЛ вам, скорее всего, не понравится.
2) Вам нечего делать в игре без знания английского на среднем уровне. Поясню об этом отдельно в самом обзоре, так что не спешите строчить свои комменты.

Всё, приступим.
В игре у нас есть 2 противоборствующие фракции: Синие Драконы (хорошие) и Культ/Незримые (плохие). И тут то сразу первое отличие и первый плюс: плохая фракция выбирается случайно, так что каждая игра отличается от предыдущей больше, чем в аналогах. Чтобы все это дело сбалансировать также есть нейтральные классы, которые могут играть с любой из фракций, а то и вообще против всех. Против всех играет Нейтральный Убийца, который есть в каждой игре, и который создан исключительно для баланса. И тут сразу еще одна особенность: ключевая фигура - Король - может принадлежать к любой фракции, т.е. быть хорошим, плохим или нейтральным.
Классов в игре, кстати, больше 35, у каждого от 3 до 5 абилок, так что будьте готовы к тому, что первых 3-4 игры вы потратите только на то, чтобы прочитать описание классов. 
У плохих также есть абилки "переманивания", которые заставляют честных граждан сменить фракцию. В чем главное достоинство: переманив человека, он сменяет класс не на рандомный, а на схожий с тем, кем он был "при дворе", т.е. "Пьяница" становится "Алкоголиком", получая похожие абилки, "Медик" - "Травником", "Шериф" - "Маршалом" и т.д.
Как и в аналогах, есть фазы дня и ночи: в течение дня вы осуждаете людей, в течение ночи творите свои законные, или не очень, дела. Довольно стандартно.
Теперь об особенности и отличии игры, которое делает ее прекрасной - логах. У каждого есть свой блокнот, в котором вы можете (обязаны) записывать свои действия и информацию об игроках, которую вы собираете по ходу игры. Используйте лог своих действий, чтобы убедить союзников в том, что вы невиновны, или наоборот, ведите фейковый лог от лица "хорошего" чтобы вас не уличили в принадлежности "плохим". В отличии от Салема, логи здесь являются ключевым элементом игры и спрашивают за них постоянно.

Получилось немного длинно, так что вот [b]вкратце[/b]: игровой процесс значительно дополнен, усовершенствован и сбалансирован в сравнении с аналогами, но предъявляет намного более высокий входной порог.

Теперь о графике. 6лять, какая же она убогая. Тем не менее, претензий к ней я не имею, т.к., спустя минуты 3, единственное, что ты видишь, это окно чата, логи и иконки абилок. Арты на иконках вполне нормальные. Ну а из-за примитивной графики все грузятся очень быстро. 
[b]Об английском.[/b] Игра полностью на английском, все разговаривают только на нем. Я много читал, мол английский в игре примитивный, используются только игровые термины и т.д. Камон, вы собираетесь играть в текстовую мультиплеерную игру, где вы и вас пытаются нае6ать каждые секунды полторы. Да, можно играть в симулятор детектива и дотошно анализировать логи и потом писать DEDUCED и GET CARRIED, но есть ли в этом смысл? Аудитория в игре просто отличная, токсиков я почти не встретил, как и ретардов. Зато годных рофлов на английском было хоть отбавляй. 

[b]Кароче[/b], игра 3,14здата. Но только если вас устраивают первых 2 пункта в моем обзоре. 10/10. 

P.S. Ухх 6ля, длинно вышло, надеюсь работяги оценят.

38753399.review:
En l’état, je ne recommande pas le jeu. J’y ai joué moins de 2h, mais j’ai derrière entre 5h et 10h de visionnage de parties histoire de comprendre ce qui se passe.
Tout d’abord, il faut être ANGLOPHONE. Si vous ne parlez pas anglais, arrêtez là.
Pour résumer rapidement, vous êtes 16, chacun récupère un rôle parmi 40+ (unique ou multiples, ça dépend). Vous avez 3 grands groupes, les Blue Dragons (BD) en bleu et « gentils », les Unseen ou le Cult, violet ou rouge pour des « méchants » et des personnages neutres qui ont leur propre condition de victoire (Exemple : Le fool doit se faire pendre pour gagner). Le tout sous la férule d’un roi qui peut être gentil, neutre, ou méchant, ce qui est très malin puisqu’on ne peut donc pas lui faire confiance.

Allez, on lance !
Très grande peur tout d’abord puisque le menu n’était franchement ni beau, ni intuitif. Je ne croyais même pas qu’il y avait de tuto mais il y en a bien un en fin de liste. Pas super lisible en l’état. En fait je vais le répéter, le jeu EST MOCHE. Je sais, on n’est pas là pour ça, mais il est juste vomitif. C’est une 3D infecte qui je l’espère sera retravaillé et c’est mon espoir profond.  (Ah non, il est sorti comme ça)
Je ne vois pas l’intérêt de faire dans ce cas précis un jeu 3D. D’autres jeux comme « Town of Salem » ont fait un choix beaucoup plus intelligent en mettant des graphismes qui se voulaient fun. Là, on dirait du sérieux des années 90. Genre le mec a tout donné et le résultat c’est du caca de première année de 3D.

Me voilà donc dans mon premier rôle. Alchimiste, un neutre. Ça tombe bien c’était l’une de mes dernières vidéos regardée. Alors il faut déjà passer la première nuit. Car oui, ce magnifique jeu à cette composante complètement aléatoire d’un premier meurtre la première nuit, comme ça. Salut.
On est 16. Le prince peut exécuter quelqu’un (sur quelle base ?), il y a potentiellement un assassin méchant et un assassin neutre. L’assassin méchant connait ses alliés, donc 1 chance sur 13 ? Le neutre peut faire ce qu’il veut, 1 chance sur 15 Allez, en gros on a quand même un pourcentage non négligeable de crever comme ça, directement. De votre côté et dépendant de votre rôle, vous aurez 1 chance sur 14/15 de faire quelque chose d’intéressant pour votre camp, de façon plus ou moins aléatoire. C’est… inintéressant ?
Là où on tombe dans la déduction potentielle et la stratégie c’est en devinant en fonction des actions des morts des informations sur les vivants. Sachant qu’en gros les seuls infos viables viennent des BD quand ils meurent (aucune raison de mentir) et des gens sur le général (et encore)… On doit se baser sur ça pour réduire le champ d’action et trouver nos ennemis. A moins de se faire accuser sur le général parce qu’on n’a pas parlé. Ou de se faire tuer la 2nd nuit pour les mêmes raisons que la première.
Le temps entre les actions semble long mais il est assez court devant la masse d’information à traiter quand on commence. La communauté n’aide pas beaucoup. Mais ils ne vous louperont pas si par malheur vous faites la moindre erreur. Et oui, je suis un idiot, stupide et autre gentilles choses. Pourtant je suis venu préparé. 

La courbe d’apprentissage est trop haute par rapport à l’intérêt mais surtout l’AMUSEMENT que j’ai pu éprouver en jouant à ce jeu. Il manquait de la finesse, de la fourberie, et d’autres éléments qui me laissaient ressentir une réelle tension que je recherchais en réalité. Un sentiment « J’ai bien protégé ma fenêtre, j’espère qu’ils ne penseront pas à ma porte » au lieu d’un « Et merde, je suis mort ce soir, salut ».
Suivant.

38742838.review:
Absolutely terrible onboarding process. Logs are the only language accepted in this game and new players will have an absolutely miserable first half dozen games until they figure out the shorthand required for log taking and they will still be unable to play evil classes without having had a chance to see pretty much all of the good classes so they can fake logs. The community guides are all wrong, either pertaining to outdated versions or suggesting "easy" lies that are so obvious to the playerbase that claiming them truthfully will get you killed half the time. And that doesn't even count the enormous numbers of edge cases you have to memorize to make decisions. 

Get past that, and you can see I got my money's worth, incredibly addictive for a while but a flash in the pan like PUBG and for similar reasons. You can play 20 games and you'll maybe see 2 good ones that are down to the wire where something actually interesting happens. 10 of those you play classes that are a simpler flow-chart than Ken, who literally have no plays other than "grief someone randomly" until late game and then their flow-chart is just the same action over and over and whose only contribution to the detective game is dying and hoping when their logs spill out of their corpse that "Couldn't grief this random guy due to blockage" is the last evidence the sleuths need to crack the case. And about 16-18 of those, the good mob or the evil mob will throw the game on a boneheaded play or through miserable random chance. Maybe the rare good game is worth it, but I play games, not slot machines or gacha.

The only memorable moments I can even name, the only times I remember winners and losers having a sportsmanlike cheer/groan of a well-fought battle in this game are when the Fool makes a strong play. And the Fool's only goal is to trick everyone into executing him. In most every other game I'm infuriated at my allies or feeling pity for the moronic play of my enemies.

So it's like PUBG, there's a lot of tension, when you're past the newbie sinkhole and into figuring out the tricks and you're figuring out the rules of the game and it seems like there are so many possibilities ahead of you, it's a buffet you can't get enough of. Only then, a dozen or two plays later, you realize you're faffing about blindly half the time and going through the motions the other half and failing at every action and getting sniped out of nowhere in the third half... you burn out just as fast as you started, from 0 to 100 and back to 0 again. I can't say I didn't get my money's worth out of both PUBG and ToL but a point comes in both where you just don't want to play it any more and can't understand anyone who still does.

38720682.review:
I bought this game because of how fun it looked on Moonmoon's stream and it definitely did not disappoint.  The obvious thing is to compare this game to Town of Salem and in my experience this game is far better.  In Town of Salem you get AFKers and leavers that leave the game to the chance the sheriff will find the killing factions.  In Throne of Lies, its completely different.  Each role feels to make contributions to their faction.  The presence of neutral roles creates additional people for both Blue Dragon and killing faction to be on the lookout for.  The cult and unseen factions leading to two different styles of games.  The King having the chance to be working against you or just not truly caring about you since their goal is to survive.  My favorite (and somewhat frustrating) part of the game is how the evil faction can convert members of Blue Dragon to their faction, which can cause panic when you think they're all dead, but the game isn't over. My one complaint is it can get toxic if you suck at your role.  I've been on the bad end where I was Prince, arguably the most critical role and messed up, then got greeted by tons of report this guy because he was bad at being prince.  Other than that, there are very few things to complain about. It's been a blast to play and I would even recommend buying this game even if it isn't on sale - it's that fun and addicting.

I would also love to give a shoutout to the development team that has worked so hard on this game.  Their Discord server is active with the devs consistently getting involved with the community they have made.  They also listen to their users and have consistently added new features to add new content as well as balancing anything that needs balancing (see: priest and noble fixes that made games too easy for BD).  They take time to review reports and make justified bans when needed.  If they keep this up, the game is certain to continue to grow, which I hope to continue supporting when it happens.

38704845.review:
After hours of playing I decided to rate this game.

1. Throne of Lies is actually a Lie, they should really rename it to Throne of Luck IMO. If ur an Assassin hitting on a Wisped Princess N1 or got debbed by a Drunk, or a Sheriff checking on you right away, prepare to get executed on the table, but it's the randomness that makes it fun and refreshing so I wouldn't say it's a bad thing. btw Prince dying night 1 every game is real.

2. The game is pretty unbalanced, at low level play, the game is more fun because there are more randomness and twists in it, you get to see the good guys executing their own people on the table, but at high level play it becomes a lot more mechanical, king get claims from ppl and check conflicting claims (very tiring if you're not used to the game), whisper train everywhere, bd asks and share info, out every Neut found to get the NK,  The Blue Dragon win most of the time because:

A.) There are too many conversion immune targets,  sometimes you get hit conv immune targets like 3 nights in a row, Prince is conv immune, Fools are immune, Scorned are immune, Guarded mercs are immune, CW barriered targets are immune, NK are immune, they really should make more classes convertable instead of giving Cult an extra charge of Erradicate, it really sucks hitting on immune targets every night or so.

B.) Inq are ridiculously OP in cult games, because of the fact that every Cult member is magic while most of BD cast isn't. Mid-to-late game the Inq can just go YOLO one shot every Cult member that is a sus, they really should make some cult members non-magic.

C.) The Evil side only have one member that can attack, for the Unseen it's the Assassin, for Cult it's the CL, and they're all not occupy immune. When found or suspected, a gaey Drunk/Prince can occupy an Assassin or CL over and over (not killing, up to 3 nights) while the other members of the BD hunt for the MM or other Cult members, it becomes really frustrating and not fun if ur on the Evil side, theres basically nothing you can do against it, You can go make some coffee and return 5 minutes later only to see ur still in Jail with the Prince laughing at yout face.

There's a reason why there are so few people playing this game: At low level play the game is quite fun IMO, because of the game throws and luls, but at high level play it becomes more frustrating with the unbalanced Classes, most of the time it's just a matter of luck, the bad guys relies too much on the Neutral Killer and Evil King(which spawns too rarely)  to create chaos or early lucky (Prince) kills. If the NK died early, and there's no Fool/Scorned/YOLO Alchs, the game becomes really hard for Evil, as there's only one member that can attack (and is not occ immune), the Unseen will be figured out eventually.

Also most of the time you get only get to play boring classes like Phys or Court Wizard which sucks, the spawn chance for more interesting classes like the Fool or Scorned is too low, they really should make at least one Fool or Scorned spawn every game.

I'd rate this game a 8/10 at low level play for the random execution and game throws, and 5/10 at high level play (where there are more serious and experienced players). It's still worth getting tho ATM because the majority of the players are still very bad at the game, and I also think it's because most experienced players have already abandoned the game when they figured out what it really is. 

If you like to roll dice like me, get it, otherwise you're better off spending your time on something else.

Do you...

...Like social deduction?
...Like cheesy executions?
...Like asymmetrical gameplay?
...Like learning curves that are less of a curve and more of a spiked brick wall covered in flaming tar?

Then this game is for you.

To be more serious, this game is a brilliant little gem of a social deduction game. I've never actually played games like this so I don't have much of a basis to go off. But its time vampired away already 51 hours of my life. It probably took 10 hours to actually know what I'm doing. So be prepared to learn and get executed for not giving over your logs. Minor critisim, while the card art is good and the splash screens. The in game models are less than desirable and the animations are a bit clunky looking. Makes what is otherwise a grim thing, rather comical at times. 

There are benefits to the less technical graphics, the game loads in seconds even on my HDD with a mid range PC. So I think one could play this on a toaster if they wanted.

Finally the developer seems very active to foster a heathly community and does updates at an almost weekly basis, sometimes faster (at the time of writing this review). 38432303.review:
It's impossible to review this game without comparing it to Town of Salem, so I'm not going to even try. Most reviewers seem to be of the opinion that Throne of Lies is a through and through upgrade on that title; my opinion is that it's a bit more complex than that.

Let's start with the aspects where Throne of Lies is an improvement over Town of Salem:

* The interface is much, much more usable. Information is easier to access; everything is more intuitive


* All roles are more fleshed out. In Town of Salem, many roles are given impossibly difficult objectives, and no tools with which to complete them, having to basically rely on providence. Some roles are just plain boring to play. In Throne of Lies, it's a rare day when your character doesn't have at least one interesting play at his or her disposal. Most roles have more options than their equivalent role in Town of Salem


But now we get to the stuff Throne of Lies does worse than Town of Salem:

* Game balance. The number of characters in each of the two main factions fluctuates wildly from game to game, especially since the king can be aligned to any of them.


* There's a lot less deductive reasoning. Every rule in Throne of Lies has so many exceptions, and the initial setup has so much variance built into it, that it's almost impossible to deduce anything. Roles that had been "confirmed" can be converted the following night. You never know who killed whom. 

In Town of Salem, I had so many of these "Eureka" moments, where I initially scratched my head at something that seemed plain impossible, only to then have that epiphany about its only possible meaning, and go all L like over the opposition. In Throne of Lies, that never seems to happen. The only mode of play in Throne of Lies is closer to what in Town of Salem would have been the "All Any" mode.


* There's a certain sense of futility to it, thanks to questionable design choices. The main "evil" faction is capped at 3 members, and they can convert "good" members. Successfully executing enemies very often merely means that they get to convert more from your faction. When all is said and done, you rarely feel like your actions had any sort of impact on the match's outcome.


Now about the stuff both games are on even ground with each other:

*Both are butt-ugly to look at. :D
Yeah, it's a minor complaint, but I have to say it anyway.

So you might be asking, he's still recommending Throne of Lies despite everything that he just said? Yes, because even though it won't blow your mind, I do feel it's still a worthwhile experience for the asking price. And the developers are still making frequent changes to the game, so who knows. In a year or two this might have been polished into a top contender in the (admittedly very small) genre.

38394698.review:
Throne of Lies is an online multiplayer social deduction game for up to 16 players where you are given a role to play and have set objectives to fulfill in order to win the game. If you've played One Night Ultimate Werewolf and Town of Salem, this game will play similiarly. The game itself has a learning curve as you try to get yourself acquainted with all the different classes available, but thankfully there is an easy to access panel in game that can tell you what a class can/can't do. New players looking to get into playing ToL will be pleased to know there is a scripted tutorial available that teaches them about the interface and the basics on how to play the game.

Each game of ToL feels dynamic as the roles are randomized at the start of each session, alongside numbers of Blue Dragons, Neutrals, the type of evil faction and neutral killer present. The two evil factions, the Unseen and the Cult, have different playstyles but share the same goal of wiping out the Blue Dragon. It should be of note that some roles do not appear until conditions have been met; a Paladin only appears during Cult games and likewise a Sheriff only appears during Unseen games. The conversion ability that evil faction leaders possess also add an additional layer of complexity to a game as previously confirmed BD members can be instantly turned to the dark side, so it is vital that you carefully choose where to place your trust. A notepad and log is available for players to use to keep track of information they have gathered, and can be used to further their factions end game goal.

There is also room for creativity and roleplaying as you are allowed to choose your name at the beginning of a session as well as customize your character with different armors and weapons that give you a different execution emote. There are microtransactions to purchase gold, but they are not mandatory or game breaking as they provide you a faster way to get cosmetics that do not impact gameplay. The devs are also very active in terms of updates, player moderation and interaction. All in all in it's current state, it is a wonderful deception game that I can recommend, and a great buy for it's current price.

38393553.review:
This game is an interesting twist on the classic party games of Werewolf and/or Mafia. For those who are familiar with the game Town of Salem, you may see some similarities there too. It's a game about deception and deduction, and follows a very similar gameplay to the aforementioned games.

The main differences between those, and Throne of Lies, is that Throne has more depth. This depth comes from the 40~ roles (the number changes every few updates) that you can be randomly assigned in a round. While this many roles, and their unique abilities, can pose a learning floor that is higher than Mafia or Werewolf, it's worth learning if you enjoy such slueth and bluff games! I personally watched several streamers play the game for about a week before I purchased it, and this helped my learn the game before jumping in.

My first play session was 28 hours long, and I've heard some people average around 12 hours for their first time as well; so be warned, it's addictive. That said, if you enjoy bluffing and detective type games, I highly recommend Throne of Lies!

38251388.review:
This game is a hidden gem covered in dirt.

This game needs more exposure, and I would say wait for a sale but I say the 10 dollar price tag is super worth it!

Gameplay is super detailed. Lots of classes, lots of ways to play. A bit of a learning curve but there's a beginners guide found on the main menu, on the wiki and theres a discord channel filled with tons of helpful lovely people.
There's not a whole lot of skill needed... sometimes its all luck. Sometimes it's going to take your sheer brain power and manipulation to win a game. Whatever it may be, games are quick and fast and each match feels new. 

The graphics - I mean personally, I like the cartoony retro classic graphic look. On the brighter side, it looks better than Town of Salem :P.

Community - There's gonna be some people who get a bit mad and a bit toxic. A couple cuss words get thrown around but in the end, it's a game that's based on communication and working together. People are bound to get a little antsy if they're wrongly accused or a huge mistake gets made that throws the game. Happens all the time in all sorts of games. The community is not toxic at all. There's people who are mature and immature. But in the end, everyone I met so far just wants to play the game and enjoy the game without any sort of unnecessary toxicity. 

CONCLUSION - Get the game if you're into the Trouble in Terrorist town vibe, or you just like the murder mystery genre. This game, in my opinion, way better than Town of Salem, and just because it costs more than ToL, doesn't mean it's not worth giving it a try. Get the game with friends! (Just make sure not to ghost and cheat! :D)

38169477.review:
Throne of Lies is a thoroughly addicting and charming social deduction game. Every single game feels fresh and exciting and I feel like my mind gets a mini-workout each game, regardless of what faction or class I am playing (except when I play Court Wizard; fuck that class).

I’d like to touch on a couple of things that I haven’t seen mentioned much in reviews. ToL has quite a steep learning curve for such a “cutesy”, casual game, and there will be games where you will get flamed for not knowing mechanics and how the different classes interact with each other. Keep your head up, read up each class on the wiki, and watch some youtube/twitch videos. 

The other issue I’d like potential buyers to be aware of is that you may get into games where you get flamed for not doing something “popular” (but you’re not breaking any of the game rules). For example, the extremely powerful class known as the Prince generally doesn’t reveal himself, for safety reasons, however, I was in a game where the Prince outed himself immediately, asked his faction’s teammates to keep him healed/guarded, and to feed him information each day. I felt bad that he was flamed for doing something “different” – as long as what you’re doing doesn’t go against your faction’s goals and the game rules, I’m all for weird and unconventional strategies in this game.

Just be aware of this, and this is my heads up to you that I have almost 80 hours invested so far, and most games have been enjoyable and flame-free. There will be some “blah” games with some very childish people, but as far as online communities go, it’s solid and generally mature.

I think if you’re at all interested in deduction and/or social games, don’t care at all about the graphic style, and are willing to invest some time into learning the mechanics, you’ll discover a true gem of a game, with endless possibilities, combinations, and a variety of personalities in your respective teammates (and enemies). In some games, you’ll want to punch kittens due to the ridiculousness of it all, and in other games, you’ll legit get out of your chair, point your finger at your computer monitor, and roar, “GET DEDUCED”.

37905801.review:
Primero que nada, si no sabes inglés no compres este juego, actualmente solo esta disponible en inglés y solo lo juegan personas que hablan dicho idioma y en este tipo de juego tener el traductor de google abierto en otra ventana no será suficiente.

Este juego es básicamente una versión mejorada de Town of Salem, todo está mejorado y es mucho más divertido ya que cada rol cuenta con diferentes habilidades lo que amplía tus opciones, la comunidad es mejor (aunque hay varia gente tóxica pero no tanta como en ToS) y el juego es actualizado constantemente por los desarrolladores. La única razón por la que recomendaría town of salem en lugar de este juego es para la gente de habla hispana ya que ToS si tiene servidores en español.

Para los que no conocen ni Town of Salem ni lo que son los juegos de este tipo, básicamente en este tipo de juegos cada quien es asignado a una facción al azar entre tres disponibles, en este caso las facciones son "Blue Dragon", "Unseen/Cult" y "Neutral". Blue Dragon son los "tipos buenos", tienen más jugadores que las otras facciones combinadas y para ganar deben eliminar a la facción de "Unseen/cult", sin embargo no sabes quien mas esta en tu misma facción por la que te pueden engañar fácilmente. "Unseen/cult" son los tipos malos y son dos facciones distintas pero solo una de las dos aparecerá, ellos empiezan con dos miembros pero pueden convertir a los miembros del "Blue dragon" para incrementar sus numeros. El objetivo de "Unseen/cult" es matar a todos los miembros de "Blue dragon". Finalmente estan los neutrales que viven en su propio mundo y tienen sus propias condiciones de victoria separadas de las demás facciones.
El truco del juego yace en tratar de ver através de las mentiras de los jugadores para saber en quien puedes confiar y en quien no, además para ayudar a esto cada jugador tiene un rol que se le asigna de manera aleatoria, cada rol tiene sus propias habilidades y atributos que les ayudan a alcanzar la victoria.

En conclusión, el juego es muy entretenido y vale la pena incluso a precio completo siempre y cuando tengas un buen nivel de inglés.

The fact that people can be converted as the game progresses and that there is a neutral killer aligned with no one means that there's a lot of ways games can go down. Add into that the mind games associated with sharing information and faking logs and it gets interesting really quickly.

37781762.review:
This game takes mafia/werewolf to a whole new level. If you enjoy those games but don't enjoy the setup, explaining rules and gathering people then this might be for you.

Some might compare this to Werewolf, EpicMafia or Town of Salem/SC2 Mafia but its really unique in its own sense. It brings the best elements of all those and puts them together with a very active development/balance team. If you've played them and are afraid that this game won't be fresh, let me assure you that it is VERY fresh and you will enjoy it immensely if you've played previous titles with the same theme.

For some examples of great things that this game brings along. This game offers slightly longer day time for more discussions, it offers a leading role in all games (mayor known in other games and King in this one), all roles have abilities which leads to more complexity and limiting math solves until the very end. The only time it should and is feasible to fully rule out who is evil. In addition neutrals have very strong powers to help them stay neutral and similar to Town of Salem, the sound track is amazing. I cannot recommend this game enough.

Now I mentioned it took the best elements of mafia games to bring together, what else does it bring? Well it brings new character screens and animations. Each character has their own night scene depending on their role, there are a couple death scenes so dead (town) court members don't just show up dead in front of their house the next day. It gives better immersion in my opinion. Town of Salem and Epic Mafia was meant to run in a browser but this game runs on a game engine. That means the possibility of more custom day and night scenes, custom execution scenes and a customization options that not only make you look better but have an effect on your animations. Town of Salem only had your death animation, this has the executioner's animation instead which changes based on your weapon. Its amazing.

Don't take my word for it, I highly recommend you try it out. If you don't like it then you could always refund it but its dirt cheap anyway and updates are coming in quick and fast. Its worth the price and I recommend it.

The classic Werewolf lacked depth in form of classes. Hell, sometimes you even lacked people to play a proper round. In this game, you are not just a simple class. Your class matters, because you actually have abilites in the day/night phases of the game. You can use them. And hell, even if you are dead - you can still be of use to classes that can talk to the dead. Or reanimate the dead.

To be honest, I can't really describe the game. If you are somewhat able to speak english and like these types of "deceit" and "lying" games - buy it. You won't regret it.

37579479.review: At first this game is rather fun. You learn a few of the ins and outs. You get to have some random roles, and after a while you get really sucked in. After a lot of time invested though you start to recognize a lot of issues that kill the enjoyment. Certain abilities don't have full descriptions, neither in the game nor on the wiki's. Classes become bugged out where certain abilities stop working properly (MM's being completely unable to convert anyone, assassin's unable to kill, etc). New patches introduce loads of new bugs, or imbalanced gameplay issues. In the end I found myself usually closer to enraged than happy and content with playing this game. I'm not downvoting this game because I think the concept is bad or even that the execution is terrible. I'm down voting it because I personally feel it's bad for my mental health.
37579479.developer_response:
First, we thank you for 200 hours spent on our game.

Second, we apologize for some of the bugs -- we're just an indie team with 2 actual programmers (that's why we're only 10 bucks), but we plan to expand after all the recent support ~ we've already taken recent feedback into consideration and opened a public test realm, available from our Discord ( https://discord.gg/tol ) to better test new patches. 

Most bugs are generally addressed within days, when compared to other games that may take weeks to months. Although we try our best, some bugs do slip through due to the unlimited combinations of classes. Sometimes we have some unexpected bugs. Some frustrating, some funny: https://youtu.be/y8G43mXUXqk
As for balance, we're at the dreamly 50% balance with only a 5% offset, which is something even AAA games have trouble achieving. We hope we have already shown that we will continue to balance (we went from 60% to 50% in only a month of balance suggestions from the community), with the same offset considerations. We'll keep trying to lower this offset, even more.

If the bugs are killing you, come back in a couple weeks and perhaps your feeling may be different. It doesn't take us long to fix stuff. Hope you try us again.

PS -- you may want to post your feedback on Discord in the proper hub. We don't take feedback directly from reviews, although we keep it in the back of our mind.

(Edited for grammar)

To start, I think the concept and core of the game is great. It is fun to play ..... when everyone else is decent.... I know you can find whoever playing online. If people are shitty to each other - at least for me - it isn't fun (and can cause worse reactions). If people play along and just have fun and act decent, it can be a good time. I know this game has gotten quite a bit of attention on twitch, so I can see where the crowd is coming from. 

So, if you are fine with people shitting on you if you mess up and being called an idiot and having a lot of salt thrown your way if you mess up - then this game can work for you

If you want to treat other like human beings and treated back as such or can't deal with that kind of destructive criticism pulled your way, steer clear. Also, if you deal with depression or anxiety the community will just worsen it with their behavior. I know this as I deal with some anxiety and have resulted in some anxiety attacks from this community (resulting in me unable to sleep until 3 am). So do what is best for yourself.

I know the developers have made a fun game they work so hard on, it is just sad that it seems the wrong crowd has joined in and soiled the game. I will still be playing the game in small sessions, just wanted to point this out incase people in a similar mindset want to play this game.

36778341.review:
Think of a social deduction game like Mafia, Werewolf, Resistance, or Town of Salem, that has a medieval kingdom theme, gets consistent character/feature/cosmetics/balance updates every few days, has an awesome community and a dev team, and worth every penny of its full price. That is Throne of Lies. Is it flawless though? I can only say not yet, but it is pretty close.

There are some bugs here and there, which are getting fixed every patch. There are a few imbalanced classes as of this review's date, such as Inquisitor. This is likely to change though because if you take a look at updates section of the game, you can see the number of patches they've made thus far and see how much effort they put to make the game better.

So all in all, it's a highly addictive super fun game which has a wonderful community and hard working devs that are trying to make the game even better. 10/10 would buy at the full price again.

Edit: I recommend watching some gameplays or streams before playing though. There are 42 classes, and it is kind of hard to grasp everything before seeing how a game usually plays.

Update 13.12.2017: Inquisitor has been nerfed, and Sorcerer got a buff. It feels a bit more balanced now but we'll see.

36764905.review:
This game is amazing, I have played TOS and TOL and TOL triumphs TOS.
Why? Well, in TOS the days were too short in my opinion. There wasn't enough to time to properly discuss what you've found and there are toxic people even on that game.
I'm not saying TOL doesn't have toxic people on there game, every game does, but the DEVs do their best to connect with their people and fix problems quickly. In TOS i've seen them ignore the demands more often than not.
For example, in TOL very few people liked the royal blood which replaced check allies on King. What the Devs did? They reverted it back to check allies.
Everyone complained about the new noble. What did the Devs do? They removed noble. They tried to make him useful but people would spam Hearasy.
I don't see TOS devs trying their best to please the people.

Also, those bad reviews are usually revenge reviews or people who just got banned for cheating. Don't cheat, play the actual game and then you won't get banned.
This game has problematic areas like every other game but it's amazing, the community is great despite those toxic weeds that pop up everytime.

The community is very helpful and fun, and I really enjoyed playing PTR and LIVE with them!
Also, I'm glad they do PTR to allow us to test the new build before it comes out and they can fix the problems we spot.

In TOS it can get repetitive and boring quickly, as it's always Mafia, and some sort of NK. 
But in TOL it's either Unseen or Cult, and you have to keep guessing which it'll be. I've played games where we never knew what type of game it was until we FINALLY killed one of the Unseen/Cult.
Plus, every role can be converted except only a few.

Overall, I really enjoy this game. It may not be everyone's cup of tea but it sure is mine! It makes you work hard to figure out who the killers are. If there is no prince, you have to take the chance of killing a fool, If there is no investigate you have to figure out another way to find the killers.
One smart game used the Inquisitor, who is an investigative role, to find the Sorcerer and the Cult, because Cult uses magic.

36575675.review:
If you are looking for games that requite deduction and logic, this is the exact game for you. Throne of Lies (ToL) is a variation of the popular Mafia social game whereby you will either be on the side of the Blue Dragon (Good), Cult/Unseen (Evil) or the forsaken Neutrals. ToL is also often compared or described as Town of Salem (ToS) in 3D, which I can agree to a certain extent as they have the same core gameplay but currently ToS has much more content in terms of roles and meta.

The gameplay for ToL is extremely addictive, provided that you are willing to commit mistakes and learn more about the game as the games could be tainted with toxicity due to salty/stupid players at times (I admit I do get salty too). Winning the game is very satisfying as you tend to be emotionally invested into the game as you could be wrongly framed, caught out being as an evil but turning it around etc etc.

However, a word of warning for beginners who are new to the Mafia game genre, you could try out ToS on the web browser for free before jumping into ToL. This allows you to understand the overall mechanic of Mafia games and provide a smoother transition into ToL as the players in this game could be quite unforgiving towards newbies.

As of 18/11/2017 and being a player for a month, I would recommend this game because the developers are consistently updating the game and tweaking the "unfun" classes like Court Wizard/Noble from the feedback of the players. This shows that the dev team are listening to the players and making positive changes to the game in order to better the gaming experience for the players. $10 for possibly hundreds of hours in gameplay is very much a steal, even more if you are looking to make a purchase during sales.

EDIT: I voted this game for the "The World Is Grim Enough Let's Just All Get Along" Steam Award

36571979.review:
My background for social deduction games of this sort comes from Resistance/Avalon board games, although I've played a bit of One Night Werewolf and Coup as well. ( I haven't played ToS, the obvious game everyone compares it to)

The game is very addictive, and a lot of fun. It's very frequently updated with patches ( too frequently, if you can imagine that ), so it keeps constantly changing - it really brings out the sentiment that devs are intent on improving it.

There is a great variety of classes you can end up getting, with various powers and win conditions, most of which are quite fun, with a couple of boring ones. Most of the game is about being either good at lying, or at catching other people in a lie. Communicating and deducing information quickly as well, of course. Being a fast typist helps too.  

Some gripes I have with the game:

- The game is a bit nonintuitive at first in terms of how night abilities interact, and what interactions return which messages. It will take a while to learn those, and even when you do, they are constantly being changed with patches. 
- As with every game of this sort I imagine, you cannot really play them together with your friends if you intend on sharing information before the game is finished, since that would be cheating. It's also kinda impossible to catch this type of cheating, so that's why I feel you can't take this game too seriously. 
- Some players will disconnect from the game, leave on purpose, out their teammates because they didn't want to be converted, all of which can ruin it for the other 15. I am not sure how serious the team behind the game is about punishing this behavior yet - they say they are on discord, but I would love to see some public announcements on how people are being punished.

----

Currently there is only one mode of play, unranked, but at least the waiting queues are short since there seem to be a lot of players at all times.

9/10, easily worth $10, even at this stage with all its warts, and I imagine it will only be getting better since devs seem to be very active.

2. disconnects. okay, so there are disconnects. however, there's this handy-dandy little contraption called the "reconnect" button whenever your game crashes that brings you back into the server you were just on.

3. the devs. okay, i see this alot: "oh i told devs to let me play like blah blah blah and they banned me!!!" or "devs are oppressing me and are sexist communist germans!!!" or similar. devs actually care about this game, and give FREQUENT, RELEVANT updates EVEN after alpha/beta testing - which i participated in. The ORIGINAL, no-edits ToL game in beta was FAR different from the current game. Most factions had different names - most obvious being the "Black Rose" which was changed to "Unseen" (thankfully). Many new classes have been added, old classes changed, and unbalanced classes (priest - the horror) removed after direct feedback on the community discord. The devs release patch notes quite a while before the actual update, so we know what's coming soon - in fact, earlier today a new set of patchnotes was released for the next update that adds two new neutral classes which, just from theory standpoint, already add much variation to each game they're in.

4. no i am not a "fanboy" because i "recieved this product for free". i did not technically recieve it for free, BUT i recieved it for free on steam and bought it (for 15$) from their own website during beta testing.


also yes i realize i did not use any punctuation in any of that


i know how to use punctuation i swear

edit 2: to be honest, this game isn't really enjoyable until you actually learn how to play decently. in the first hour, you'll be bumbling around as an important blue dragon/unseen/cult role and your team members will be angry at you for being bad. it happens. however, it also helps to spend a good 10-15 minutes looking over the wiki/in-game class cards. social games usually aren't fun at first, ToL isn't the exception. especially because you actually have to think sometimes (woah) and can actually suffer hard for mistakes made in-game. 

i've also seen people complaining about how there's no mode seperation.
the devs have posted (in the p u b l i c discord) that they are planning on adding a seperate competitive matchmaking for more experienced players. there ALSO used to be a seperate gamemode besides base ToL that had entirely different roles, was a smaller group size (usually 6 players per game), and was faster as a consequence.

36307338.review:
While on the topic of Town of Salem, I'm gonna bring up the game Throne of Lies. At first glance it just looks like a copy of Town of Salem but it is so so so much better in my opinion. And I say that as someone with probably 30+ hours in ToS. First off, there's so many more roles in the game, but not enough so that it gets exhausting. It's like the perfect amount so that it keeps the game very fresh without being a slog to learn everything. Additionally, the game has a very streamlined built in class list that tells you every single thing about the class, so you don't need to worry about not knowing what class do.
So the way the game plays is as follows: The "Good" faction is the Blue Dragon, and they're in every game. Then it randomly chooses a "Bad" faction, either the Unseen or the Cult. The Unseen is like the traditional mafia, The Cult is a bit weirder. Every game has a Prince, a King, , 2 of either The Cult or The Unseen, 2-4 Neutral classes and 8-10 random Blue Dragon classes. The king can be Good, Evil, or Neutral which makes for very interesting games.
The game plays pretty much the exact same as ToS. A 90 second day for discussion and voting for treason followed by a 30-45 second night (can't remember which). However, this gameplay is where ToL is ahead of ToS by leagues. First off, there is not a single dull class in ToL. For example, in ToS, if you get Survivor or Retributionist, it's pretty boring because you can't really help your team win directly through what you do. Obviously with the survivor all you have to do is live, which is really boring. Nobody wants to do nothing except for survive. It's fun to learn secrets about people and be involved in the game, and the survivor actively stops you from that. Additionally, the Retributionist can be extremely valuable to the town, but the only thing they can do is revive someone. It can be one of the most valuable skills in the game, but the player doesn't feel like they did much. ToL gets rid of those issues entirely.
First off, every single class has at least 2 abilities, some have up to 4. The abilities are split into Day and Night abilities. Day abilities can obviously be used during the day and they have an immediate impact. For example, look at Political Pressure on The Aristocrat. It forces a player to vote another player up for treason and remove their ability to vote again. You can use this to completely screw over another player by making them look super suspicious. It's a very fun and unique ability. On the other hand, Night abilities are used during the night and almost always have their effects done at the end of the night. For example, look at the Psychic's Link Minds. At night she has the ability to link her mind with 2 other players, allowing the to talk privately during the night. This is an example of an ability that doesn't occur at the end of the night. This is another very cool and useful ability.
Every class is able to directly influence other players in the game and learn about them or kill them, which makes for much more fun games. Many of the abilities are so unique and cool that it adds much more flavor to the game than ToS. For example, look at the Illusionist, the Unseen version of the Psychic. She has an ability where she can delete the chat history of a player. That is such a fantastic idea for an ability like holy shit! It has the potential to completely ruin a player's day it such a cool way. The game is sprinkled with awesome abilities like this.
The Unseen and the Cult are able to stay relevant throughout the entire game. Both of them have leaders which are able to convert Blue Dragon people to their faction, with each BD class having its own unique Unseen class. You could play the game for so long and still never experience all the classes because of how the conversions work. It takes such a specific set of circumstances to get any given Unseen class.
All in all the game is just a much better version of ToS, especially because the playerbase isn't divide between DLC and Non-DLC. If you love ToS, this game is definitely worth picking up.
