36297325.review:
A fantastic social deduction game similair to Werewolf or Mafia games only with a conversion mechanic. This increases the skill-ceiling immensely and ensures every game is unique: in other words, it is like ToS for clever people ;)

The design and graphics of the game is honestly beautiful, it is all set in a Medieval castle called Castle Adiart, and each class has their own unique bedroom which you see every night. In the morning all the dead bodies are found in a random location of the castle, giving it a real murder-mystery vibe. On top of that there are tons of cosmetic items which you can buy with money EARNED THROUGH THE GAME to increase your immersion at no real expense. 

For me the best thing about ToL is the community. As it is a social deduction game by far the most important enjoyment factor is the players around you - how your team mates act, how toxic they are. The Mods and Devs work tirelessly to get rid of any trolls or toxic players (which are normally few and far between) which can be evidenced by the vast amount of salty reviews from trolls who have been banned :D. The Discord server is a great friendly place, and the Imperium42 forum is so friendly to the point that I am suspecting everyone else may be NPC's. 

All in all 100% worth the 10 quid and will guarantee hours of gameplay.

36296262.review:
Easy-to-learn player-driven gameplay that is intense and enjoyable. Even the most casual player suddenly plays to win with the best of their abilities making the game a better experience for everyone. No one can know for sure what exactly is going on, only making up a scenario to play around as many games are decided at the actual end of the game, showcasing exquisite game design. Even dying in this game keeps the fun going as it doesn't mean your game is over as the rest of the players put the pieces together with your role and previous actions as important variables in their scenario.

The Devs and Support are amazing and hard-working, balancing + improving the gameplay frequently as well as punishing the right offenders.

This game took me completely by surprise and stole my soul. I greatly recommend it to anybody ever.

36283519.review:
It's hard for me to review this game because I don't really know what to compare it to.
My best attempt to categorize it is to call it a PVP version of Papers, Please, but with a fantasy setting. I don't think it's a very good description, but it's the best I've got.

The game is very fun, especially for the low price, and it has (at time of writing) quick queues for matches and a good community. Each match is pretty much always fun, and it only gets better once you get familiar with the rules and mechanics. Graphics are unimportant for this type of game, and I appreciate being able to run it on pretty much any computer that isn't more than a decade old.

Only issue that I can think of is that every patch so far has changed the rules a bit. Always read the patch notes. Developers are clearly trying to find the right balance for a few mechanics, and that's a good thing, but in a game with such emphasis on knowing the mechanics, a sudden change in mechanics can be very disorienting.

The only suggestions I have are that I would like to see enduring statistics for individuals. I don't want anything public, necessarily, but I'd like to know how many times I've won while playing the Prince, etc. 

And maybe consider putting the King in slot 1 on roster by default. Sometimes feels like whoever's #1 in a game is thrown under the bus by their prominent placement. Since there's always a King, I'd think the King would go in that most prominent position by default. Of course, #16 is also marked out, but not as much as #1 is, I think.

Also, the Physician having to choose between healing and exhuming puts him at a great disadvantage, so much so that it's rare to see anyone use Exhume to great effect. I think if Exhume were a daytime ability (I know graverobbing is not a broad-daylight activity, but bear with me) it would make Physician preferable to the Alchemist for some people, and would also keep the Physicians from being too bored in the daytime (where they presently have no abilities and generally no reason to engage the other players).

Other than that, I have no suggestions. One of the best I've played in a long time.

36279061.review:
Менее казуальный клон Town of Salem, который в свою очередь клон SC2:Mafia. 

Минусы:
- Неуклюжый оконный интерфейс чата взят почти без изменений от оригиналов. Хотя там есть вкладки, которые слегка отсеивают лишнее, он все равно слишком захламлен и сложно вычленить полезную инфу. И нет каких-либо настроек, чтобы это поправить... для отдельной игры халтурно.
- Игровые режимы, пока вроде есть только Casual, в котором тип класса (аля investigation) имеет слабое влияние на игру, т.к. роли распределяются не по ним, а тупо 7-9 BD, 2-4 Neutral.
- Классы, по сравнению с Салемом - их много, а в сравнении с мафией - их мало.
- Они какие-то ватные, тоже казуальные. Например вместо Vigilante с 3 выстрелами сделали Хантера, который может пускать собачку, которая кусает и от нее через день можно умереть от кровотечения. И ее можно пустить не ранее 3й ночи. Я конечно все понимаю... Jester теперь не убивает рандомного голосовальщика, а просто на 1-2 дня не дает вешать. Вот у Хантера прикольнее, он сразу убивает стрелой первого проголосовавшего за его смерть - эт да, весело.
- Нет звуковой составляющей, типов смерти тоже вроде нету, рандомные трупы показываются. Есть только Physician, который может вскрыть труп и узнать класс который убил. Короче опять упрощения.
- Графика/анимация как в дешевой браузерке.. позорище. 
- Есть определенный дисбаланс, типа Приста (ака городской амнесиак?), он обязательно присутствует в игре, его нельзя сконвертировать, он может пережить атаку, а весь его геймплей сводится к тому, чтобы оживить принца (ака jailor) когда того убьют, а потом написать новому "дружбану" - что ты прист. UPD: "PRIEST HAS BEEN REMOVED" ))
- Нужны знания английского языка, т.к. все общаются на нем и нет каких-то "российских серверов" - если ты будешь мычать что-то невнятное/понимать половину из написанного то ты играть не сможешь. 

Плюс:
- Интересная задумка с королем, аля развитие майора - который был по своему прикольный (т.к. неизвестный и рандомный).
- Коронование, если первый помрет. В итоге им может стать рипер и потом даже выиграть.
- Конвертация в "злых" происходит гармоничнее, а Культисты теперь обладают абилками-классами (а не тупо культист)... т.е. скорее как альтернативная мафия, но минус тут, что они не могут быть в 1й игре (либо-либо), раньше вроде культисты (нейтралы-евилы) могли быть одновременно с мафией.
- Аватарки персонажей.
- Все же получше Салема.
- Возможно я слишком критично подошел к "оказуаливанию", ибо писал по памяти (играл в мафию давно.. обилок там вроде меньше, но кажутся более насыщенными).. а тут часто две ночных/1 дневная.
- Игру активно правят, на следующий день вышел довольно большой балансный патч.


Покупать если ты большой любитель или ждать улучшений, скидки в 40%. Отзыв пофикшу, если будут положительные изменения.

In all, many flaws of the games design. Do not recommend purchasing. Town of Salem or Epic Mafia are better, free alternatives.

36253395.review:
Juego muy recomendable si probaste en su día Town of Salem. Y si no lo probaste también deberías echarle un ojo a este tipo de juegos, en el que cada partida puede ser muy distinta a las demás y donde se pondrá a prueba tu ingenio.

Throne of Lies es un videojuego muy reciente que va continuamente añadiendo nuevo contenido, con unos desarrolladores que realmente escuchan a los jugadores.

Las diferentes clases tienen mecánicas muy originales en general. Algunas clases son variaciones de las vistas en Town of Salem, como por ejemplo el Prince (Jailor en Town of Salem), pero la mayoría tienen características inéditas. 

Es mucho más complejo que ToS, ya que las clases poseen habilidades durante el día y la noche, y por supuesto, el novedoso sistema del Rey.

De los gráficos voy a comentar lo evidente: no es su fuerte, pero tampoco este tipo de juego lo necesita. Es el primer juego de este género que se atreve con los gráficos 3D. Las ilustraciones se nota que están hechas con mucho mimo, así como el diseño del libro de última voluntad. Por último, es muy positivo que se pueda dibujar en la deathnote, y la inclusión de las notas privadas, muy útil para evil roles.

La música crea muy buen ambiente en las partidas.

La comunidad es bastante decente. Existe un Discord para contactar directamente con los desarrolladores, compartir el enlace a tu lobby, comentar temas relativos al juego, informar de errores, etc.

En cuanto a las microtransacciones, no afectan al gameplay, ya que lo único que se puede comprar son objetos de personalización de tu personaje.

36253193.review:
A meager 10 hours is not sufficient for me to claim to be a capable player in this game, but enough hours to ensure that Throne of Lies really is a fine game for fans of Hidden Role and Social Games. Tabletop games like Avalon and Battlestar Galactica are what introduced me to this genre and Throne of Lies really takes what they have to offer and ups the ante with various roles and ways to interact.

While the idea of the game is not anything new, its execution is delightful. The various roles take time to thoroughly learn and the social aspect of the game ensures that gameplay doesn't get dull quickly. The game is constantly updated (at least now, few weeks from the launch) and balance changes seem a delightfully important duty for the developers.

I have to give negative comments on the technical functionality. The UI is ugly, sometimes the game hangs when connecting to a game and joining the game as a group of friends is wonky at times. Especially for roles that have things to do on the first day and night the wonky connection can prove very annoying.

This aside, Throne of Lies has quite unique attraction to it. The simple presentation is immediately forgotten after the game starts and all player focus is aimed at the action itself. The technical problems will hopefully the ironed out and balance perfected. I wasn't sure if I should get this game at first, but I'm glad my friends decided for me.

36244556.review: Это потрясающая игра, жаль только, что она англоязычная и нет русских серверов, но тут такие интриги идут до самого конца, просто улёт. Да, возможно, ты будешь погибать первый, но это случается редко, зато как ты потом ломаешь голову над тем кто есть кто, завербовали ли враги твоего союзника, кто играет за основные роли и самое главное какой Король на самом деле (а там он может быть 3 типов). Очень много разных ролей, как же тяжело играть в эту игру, если ты плохой, то придумываешь много разных отмазок, притворяешься другими ролями, а потом предаешь, да еще и нужно не попасться, не проколоться, а это очень тяжело. Играть за добрых мне больше нравится и неважно какой класс имхо. Ах да, самое главное правило этой игры - "Если ты Король, то будь им до самого конца!".

36243882.review:
Fun game, however the moderators are very hands on.

This is a pretty fun game, but if you do anything against the current meta, you risk being warned or moderated. 

I've been warned several times, but this one in particular irks me:

I'm priest, which is a very important class for the blue dragon. During the update I was playing priest it was particularly important not to put a mark on your back. Then, a psychic links me with the king. The king has a tendency to die d4 in about half of the games, so I didn't want myself on his logs. So I didn't claim. My argument ingame at the time was "king can be evil too.. lol" or something along those lines.

The next day the psychic puts me on the stand for this, rather then waiting for any of the ACTUAL investigative classes to check me. Furthermore, they don't wait for the prince to jail me (so I could have a chance to talk to him without the others knowing). They execute me for treason on the spot. I only had 30 seconds to sum up this argument, so I said something along the lines of "One of these days you'll learn king can be not bd". Not the greatest way to put my argument, but I was under time pressure you know?

All in all, not too upset about that much. It's a social game, and I really didn't think they were going to execute me D2. But low and behold the moderators issue me a warning for throwing the game. Firstly, we WON that game. Secondly, overbearing much?

The official moderator says "Not claiming when on stand is going against BDs objectives". If you are prince or priest you just want to be quiet all game (I know because I tried whispering people on priest and I got a warning for gamethrowing there as well) and not raise attention. And I really didn't want to be on the kings notes before he proves himself. But even if I was *wrong*, there's no "social deception" if what you're allowed to SAY (outside of slurs and swears and outing friends) is restricted.

----

However, with all that said the moderators are necessary for this game. I think they are working on balancing their moderation acts and are at least taking people advice with regards to the state of the game. After originally leaving a negative review, I will review with a tentative yes, it's worth it, however avoid band-waggoning anyone who does anything off the cuff. Remember the game is very new and what appears "correct" at first glance might not necessarily be the correct choice in every game. There is room to grow in this game, but not if you ostracize the members who are attempting to play.
36243882.developer_response:
Apologies you felt singled out for just playing the game -- to clarify, warnings don't do anything except to help us with future report history and to help you understand why some people may be reporting you. We plan to later split "warnings" to a friendlier version called "info" for FYI's so it's less of that "you're in trouble" feel and more of a "heads up" sort of feel to it. 

TL;DR: Most warnings are just trying to help you prevent getting reported by the community. Warnings don't do anything against your account; just bans

36230014.review:
TLDR: This game is Town of Salem with more abilities. The developer of Throne of Lies flagged my review which said that this game was Town of Salem with more abilities, even though he previously said the exact same thing. These devs cannot handle critcism, even when it is 100% valid.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I had originally reviewed this game with a fairly simple, not very in-depth negative review. The developer of the game felt the need to respond in an extremely passive aggressive manner AND flagged my review for breaking community guidelines, which of course, it did not. After I saw that spectacle I looked around at the other negative reviews and saw that the dev had of course replied to every single negative review, either debunking the negative review or replying in a passive aggressive manner as he had done to mine. I happened to see one response from the dev regarding the differences between his game and the similar Town of Salem. 

Here is the photo of the dev stating the differences between the two games: https://i.imgur.com/2iEkQ1q.png 

Since in my previous review that had gotten flagged for breaking community guidelines had mentioned that this game was basically Town of Salem but with more abilities, I couldnt help but notice that most of his differences were ability based. What follows is a step by step breakdown of what the DEVELOPER states as the differences between his game and Town of Salem.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

King/royal ascension system: This is a pretty good difference that is NOT in Town of Salem

The next 3 points are all based on abilites: It's true this game has more abilities and I stated that in my review

In-Game Wiki: Town of Salem is a browser game, it isnt very difficult nor offputting to open a new tab and type "Town of Salem wiki"

Weapons are tied to abilities AND 99% similar to concept art: Yes, please let me use my microtransaction weapons to let people know what ability I used. Also, congratulations your models are similar to what you wanted them to be I guess, what a feature.

Reconnection and invite code system: Reconnecting is honestly a great feature that I applaud you putting into this game, however Town of Salem does not need an invite code system because you just click your friend to invite them. When trying to invite your friend in this game, sometimes they wont recieve it so you have to copy and paste an extremely long code for them to put into their game to join you. Why not just use the steamworks system to invite friends. This is not a good difference it is extremely tedious.

3D graphics AND uncompressed music: It's true that this game is 3D, but nothing within the 3D world is interactable. It's more like looking at a 3D image, which is no better than town of salem, you are still only interacting with UI elements. Town of Salem has music, but if you are really going to say that having a different genre of music is a big difference be my guest.

The only differences that aren't bogus and that the DEVELOPER of the game stated are the ascension system and the abilities. 

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

36098327.review:
Bought this game because I need to blow off some steam after studying for a major examination. 

Basic premise: there are 20-30ish classes that you can be assigned to. There's the Blue Dragon faction (the ""good guys"") who don't know the alignment of anyone else, the Unseen and Occult (the ""bad guys"") who know who's on their side, and the neutral people who are out for themselves. It becomes a game of trust building and deceit. Do you have what it takes to make people trust you? even if you're a repear waiting to stick your sickle into their back? 

In my favorite recent game, I ended up as the reaper; a stand alone class who reaps people's souls. You're all alone in this role and if the court votes to throw you out, there's little you can do about it. So what does one do? Deflect, decept, and deny. Build up relationships and then toss em away when they are no longer useful. That's the mind of a reaper. 

But the game is incredibly, incredibly complex. The dead can and do talk with the priest class meaning anyone you backstab can come back to haunt you. Observers can spy on your every move while nobles send maids to spy on your secret converstations. The prince can jail anyone but the king and demand they account for their actions all while not knowing if the king they serve under is good, evil, or neutral. In total, there are kings, nobles, dutcheses, aristocrats, priests, seers, psychic's, prince's, seers, drunks, alcoholics, reapers, cult leaders, masterminds, assassins, hunters, alchemists, fools, and many more. 

Who will lie their way to the throne? Only time will tell.


10/10 would lie my way to the throne again.

36094022.review:
I just bought this game and have been enjoying it.  If you have ever played a table top or camp side Werewolf or Mafia game and loved it, you definitely will enjoy this.  If you really like deduction games, then you will also like this. If you like Time Management games, I'd say you would also like this as both the day time phase and the night time phase have a countdown timer.  At the current price point it is definitely worth the buy.  

The only negative thing I have to say about it, and it's really not negative... is that there is a lot of information to try to keep track of.  16 players could potentially be typing in the in-game chat window where you will garner most of your knowledge and that thing fills up fast.  Thankfully, there is a history tab you can click on right above it that will show you the entire log if you need to.

The game gives you an in-game journal and private notes tab to help keep track of information though.  But be careful, the in-game journal becomes public knowledge when your character dies in the game.  This can also be a good thing though as it can also prove your innocence if you ever find yourself getting voted up for treason.

36082098.review:
Fantastic social/deduction game based on concepts used by Town of Salem. Every player is assigned a random role at the beginning of the game and every role has a unique job to fulfill in the game. None of the players know anything about eachother including things like role or faction. So the person next to you might be an ally, an enemy or a neutral role who can either help you or kill you. Or he might be a dumbass, who knows?

The game is a struggle of gathering information and figuring out who is who in order for you to reach your win condition. 

It does have flaws though. There's tons of "quality of life" features that are not present in the game but could be easily implemented with a few patches. For example, clicking your Journal icon while having the Journal already opened closes and opens the Journal again instead of just closing it. Sometimes the interaction between abilities are confusing or not explained well enough but it's not bad enough to impact your enjoyment of the game.

Closing thoughts: I love this game and I recommend it to anyone who liked Town of Salem or tabletop games in general.

36079502.review:
You have 16 players in each game and the majority are good (blue dragon) and a few evil (unseen/cult) as well as some neutral characters who try win on their own terms. The idea of the game is to figure out who is who and execute/kill players accordingly. So blue dragon will try work together to figure out who the bad people are and kill them off, whilst the bad people try kill off the blue dragons and possibly convert them. There is around 30 different characters and aside from a few that always appear in every game the rest are random. Every character has different abilities. 

Ultimately each player needs to use their abilities and also communicate information with other players in order to snuff out the opposing side in order to meet their win condition.

This game is extremely fun ONCE you understand what is happening. At the time of this review I've put in 10 hours and I'm starting to nicely understand how a lot of things work now and the more I understand about peoples roles and the game the more fun I'm having. The community is good from what I've seen so far and people try play their roles in the game accordingly which is great.

For £7 this game is great fun once you get past the initial learning curve. Would definitely recommend.

36067073.review:
Really fun and addictive game. It has a bit of a learning curve, and even after playing it for many hours there are a few roles that I hate and almost never win at, but it's great fun. I will get many hours of fun out of it, I'm sure, so it's definitely worth the $10.

A couple of complaints:

You get put into a game with 16 random people, and it really sucks when some of them aren't serious and intentionally throw the game, disconnect, etc. It doesn't happen *that* much, but enough that it's annoying. I'd like it more if instead of the current "random rooms" system, there was a centralized matchmaking system which tracked user stats and put you with people who have vaguely similar winrates and reliability.

In some ways I feel like the overall format causes classes to be underused. Like, you can *imagine* that all of the classes of the Blue Dragon or Cult or Unseen could form up into an incredible team, but it never actually happens. Everyone has to be very fast and aggressive or else you die. For example, the court wizard hardly ever has much impact because he'll usually get killed before he's able to even find his teammates.

36003136.review:
This is one of the best games I have ever played.

Purchased <2 weeks ago, have already played for 66 hours. Some of the roles I like less than others, but overall the replayability is insane... the game as a whole never gets old. Buy it.

It is chiefly a social intuition/communication game mixed with strategy/puzzle/logic. It pits two factions aginst one another with a host of "neutral" classes that make things even more messy. The variety of roles is impressive, and 16-person games are amazingly fun.

I have learned more about human nature in this game than any other game, and it is very VERY fun to take advantage once this knowledge is gained.

For example, playing as an Evil King, my goal is to destroy the team I supposedly lead without making my evil allies suspicious enough of me to kill me off. This challenge requires creativity, sublety, and constant tactical revision.

Playing as an investigative role on the good team, your job is to sniff out the bad guys. Just don't communicate too frequently or too openly with the other good guys (who you can't be totally sure of anyways and need to individually vet) otherwise you will become a target.

You get the idea. I could go on but I won't. Buy it, well worth the $10. Get a few friends interested as well and it will become even more entertaining.

35998040.review:
I came from Town of Salem(ToS) with a bit over 300 hours in ToS.

I played a few games of Thone of Lies and then uninstalled Town of Salem.  Throne of Lies is a vastly enhanced experience from the 3-d graphics, to the more comfortable and functional UI, logging system with 2 pages and a private notes page, many different roles and 2 evil factions (2 evil factions from the start without the need to pay for an upgrade like in ToS only to find no one is playing the expansion in ToS....), custom drawn death notes, fun death animations, and lots more.

It's a fantastically fun represenation of a table top experience and I'll be playing many more games, very happy with this purchase.

Recommended!

35988787.review:
I almost feel like I SHOULDN'T recommend this game, purely based on the reasoning that I've had it less than a week and have already logged 60+ hours into it. It is extremely addictive, a lot of fun, and all in all just a wonderful game to play. I have been recommending it to everyone that I know, regardless of whether or not they are a gamer.

- Extremely fun
- Very interactive
- Infinite ways to play, with new strategies being thought up every day
- A wide range of classes to play
- Each game is unique, no game is ever the same
- Great dev and community support

If you enjoy games that require a lot of logic and strategic thinking whilst also interacting with other people, this is 100% the game for you. Despite what some people have claimed in their reviews and occasionally in game, every class has a purpose; Noble is NOT useless, it is actually an extremely interesting and fun class to play, however people seem to misunderstand its role in the game and for the Blue Dragon faction. Please for the love of Cthulu, if you are Noble, DON'T use a crier on the first night, it tips off everyone in the game that there is a Noble, and you are unable to utilise one of my favourite abilities in the game, which allows you to send a maid to one player and listen in on all the whispers they send/receive. And yes, some classes are on the more OP side of the balance equilibrium, but I find this a lot fun due to causing the evil factions/classes having to try and work out which player is that class and making them their number one priority.

There is very little toxicity from the social side of things, and usually if there is toxicity during the game it is because of a specific player's agenda due to the class they are playing and is not at all personal, 90% of the toxicity I have encountered in-game has been met by an apology from the player instigating it either after they have died, or in the end-game lobby.

TL;DR - buy this game. The only thing you will regret is that you can't play it 24/7, because that's just unhealthy.

In regards to day abilities, we used to have TONS more! However, we realized (very fast) that it's really difficult to make day abilities without someone using it as an annoying meta. For example, Alchemist used to blur your screen -- then all it became was a "blur me or you're not alchemist". 

However, this doesn't mean we gave up! We're still adding day abilities as we think of rock solid ones. So if you have any ideas for day abilities that would be hard to counter with meta tactics, let us know on our Discord or Forum!

35937833.review:
If you like social deduction games such as Resistance, Secret Hitler, Mafia or Werewolf then you may like this game.  It's an online verison in which each player gets a unique class with their own abilites to help provide information in lieu of being able to use the social cues in a face to face game. Be warned though that this is a very different type of game, it involves a lot of deduction and logic.  This isn't a fast paced game and the engine and graphics are very bare.

If you've played Town of Salem, this game is far superior in my opinion.  The classes are far deeper and more interesting with all of them have multiple abilites. For example, the Priest class is a Medium and Retributonist in one, with the added ability to survive a single attack and heal someone once per game.  This makes the class far more interesting than either class is in Town of Salem.  

The classes are more balanced and varied, to the extent where the good faction doesn't need a strict role list to avoid imbalanced games.  Because classes have a wider ranger of abilites it isn't really as important which specific classes are present, since another class can often take over.  For example, the Knight Class can act as a Bodyguard, but they can also choose to attack someone at night, similar to a Vigilante. 

There is no way to spy on the evil factions at night, so they can actually cooperate. The evil roles have ways to misdirect and fool people that are far more useful.  For example, the Herbalist role (similar to doctor, but evil) can make someone think they were attacked and healed. Conversion mechanics make it impossible to simply self-confirm day 1 and then have everyone know you're good the rest of the game. 

The neutral roles are far more well thought out.  The neutral killers are actually strong and can often win, and the neutral beigns are more active.  For the example the Alchemist is like the survivor, only they can heal and have 2 kills per game, letting them influence the game instead of just vesting every night and waiting to see if you die.

The game isn't perfect, but it's definitely a step up from Town of Salem in terms of design. About the only negative is it might be a bit *too* complex and *too* deep for some people's tastes.

The game must be changed alot.

Firstly, there are too many classes that have extremely low or even zero impact in the game.

Secondly, there are extremely low chances to clearly determine if someone is a "bad" guy, unless someone has ability that directly does this (which is rare). And if "bad" guy is decent liar this is nearly impossible to determine if he is "bad", because he pretends to be another "good" class that almost cannot to be distinguished from the "bad" one. Plus, "good" guys can be turned to "bad" guys in one night, which makes determination even harder. As a result almost all executions by accusation are very random and often have no reasons at all.

Thirdly, there are key statements made by players that give you about 90% probability that those players do not lie. Because those statements are pretty easy to check and would ruin those game if they would lie.

So this game needs a serious rework to become less random and less dependent of statements in chat. It could potentially be very interesting but is not for now.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I still fear that this game can be easily ruined by strategies like "all should posts their roles and logs each day" and it can't become "professional" because of that. 35732311.review:
They're calling this a "social deception" game -- like Mafia which I had watched on some streaming events.  The game's all multiplayer and all about trust and calculated risk.  Even if you aren't an elite multiplayer gamer, as long as you can type and either see through BS or spin BS of your own, you can have fun with this game.  Player base is large enough that games are quickly found and it's also aggressively policing abusive players.  I got this game a week ago but have been really addicted and never had an angry or bad experience so far.

For the game itself -- Generally you have 16 players, 2 starting as an evil faction that always knows who they are and want to kill or take over the good guys, 8-10 on a good faction that start out clueless, with the remainder being neutral with different goals.  

There's 2 phases of the game, during the night a lot of action happens -- people get killed, people change factions, people spy on each other.  During the day everyone can talk about what happened, and if they choose they can put anyone else up for an execution vote... if enough join in, there is a trial where the person explains themself and finally everyone votes again whether to kill them or not.  

There's different good roles that can you can start with, and each of the 2 evil factions have variations of the good classes.  For neutrals, they have 6 roles with powers that depend on their objectives.

Some roles have killing powers, some can investigate and determine what type someone else is, there are communication classes that can talk to dead players or send anonymous/secret messages, and defensive classes that block many different things.

So the good side doesn't know who's who, but they want to gather lots of info with abilities and figure out how to share it... without revealing to the evil side whether they are good instead of neutral.  If the good side can figure out the evils, then they can easily vote them off.  The game is endless bluffing, literally everyone wants to be seen as allied with the good side, so you dealing in lies and liars from start to finish!

35730177.review:
The first thing I thought when playing this game, was it's similarity to the popuar game Town of Salem. However, if you dislike Town of Salem, don't let that turn you away from this game. There are a lot of key problems Town of Salem had that are absent from this game. The player base in general is better, no random lynching and no people throwing games for no reason.

The classes and factions are also much better balanced, and classes themselves are more fun to play. Instead of having only a few classes that you hope for, you can have fun playing just about every class. There are a couple of classes I personally feel don't have much impact, but the game is constantly improving, so.

The best thing about this game, is that the most important factor is most definitely the players skill. This is a game of deception and logic, and those skills are highly valuable in this game. If you are a good player, you can easily win any game if you're careful. It takes a while to get the hang of a few things, but once you do, you will have some of the most satisfying wins and comebacks.

I honestly just can't wait for there to be a larger playerbase. At any given time, there's around 300-600 people playing. This imeans there's probably 2000 active players. This is enough for you to not have any trouble finding a match quickly, but if there were more then they could start implementing a ranking system. Normally people who play games like this are competitive, so I think it would be a nice addition.

35705880.review:
I used to play hours and hours of the original mafia party game through my mid teens. Always been a fan of those kinds of games. Then I played the shit out of Epic Mafia, both with randoms and with the occasional massive /v/ room.
There are many versions of it to play online too, like Epic Mafia and Town of Salem, but I have to say, this one is by far the most polished and engaging one. 

First of all, the two current gamemodes have some focus on a mechanic of conversion. Anybody who proves to be a good guy might not STAY a good guy. It's really hard to trust anyone with that in mind, because if you do, it probably will come back to bite you.
Second of all, every role has many abilities to use during the day and/or night. You're never at the mercy of waiting or unable to do anything. Smart use of abilities and just the right amount of luck can turn games around, or completely ruin them. That does mean the learning curve is a bit higher, even if the motions are generally the same, but the game has a built-in guide that lets you see all the classes any time and a wiki that's kept tidy by the ever growing community.

In other words, if you like the mafia/werewolf kinda game of deception, this is the single best one in the market at the moment, hands down. Definitely check it out.

35689943.review:
This game is fantastic. It's a lot of fun to play and really addictive. When you first start out, plan on losing a bunch until you learn how things work. The tutorial gives you a basic rundown of how the game works, but you really need to spend some time in the game to figure it all out. 

There is a lot of strategy to learn for this game, and things change from game to game. I love how you always get a different role each game, and you aren't always on the same faction, and no one knows what they will be until the game starts. This keeps things fresh and interesting. Plus, since players can be converted to another faction mid-game, sometimes your strategy will completely pivot (and sometimes you can be pulled off the losing side on to the winning one.) 

The game does have a few bugs to be worked out, and my game does crash from time to time, but for a $10 game still in beta it's worth every penny. 

Besides the occasional crash, the only downside to this game is having to play with really dumb people from time to time. There are a lot of different skill levels among the players, and really dumb and clueless people can be super frustrating (unless you are the one trying to take advantage of the dumb people, and then it's cool.) 

This is my favorite game of the year, and it's definitely worth picking up for $10 or less. Just make sure to play your few games with an open mind until you have had a chance to learn how things work.

35669605.review:
Once again, Mafia fails to be captured in an online game.

You just can't take mafia and make it a digital game, you have to contribute to changing the fundementals of the game.
The King is the best feature that this redesign has, but it fails to change the fundemental mechanics of the original party game.

I wrote an extended letter to the devs, I highly reccommend reading it if you're at all interested in this kind of game. 

Letter to the Devs - https://pastebin.com/wmmB467A 

Mafia is fun because there is no opportunity to metagame. You have to read reactions, faces, body language, and speach in addition to actions. All of these subtleties are lost on a digital version. Town of Salem falls to the same problems that Throne of Lies has.

Games like Trouble in Terrorist town (Garrys Mod), while flawed are superior to Throne of Lies because it changes the fundemental way the game is played.

In Mafia, all the players sit in a room and play according to the honor rule of not reading your card aloud.
In Town of Salem and Throne of Lies, players sit in different rooms, and play by the same rules, with the honor rule unenforced.
With TTT, players are not trying to emulate the same game. You're forced to play differently, even if the goal and idea is the same. It's not just MAFIA BUT ONLINE, it's "Like mafia, but with shooting and crime solving"

It's not good and I don't reccommend it to anybody, even if it has good ideas.

This game is my new addiction. It's everything I hoped Town of Salem was. ToS is still a great game for players that want a simple easy to understand experience, but if you're looking for a game with a little more complexity to it, this is perfect.

Each day & night cycle is exciting, each class has multiple abilities, some usable during the day, and some at night. I haven't played a class I don't like yet, all of them feel fairly balanced and fun.

35661366.review:
Il s'agit de ma toute première évaluation sur steam, sur plus de 200 jeux.

Je suis tombé dessus complètement par hasard dans mes recommandations journalières, j'ai tenté, et je me suis retrouvé sur une perle.
Si vous êtes allergiques aux interactions sociales, passez votre chemin : ce jeu est un jeu de déduction sociale, à la manière de Town of Salem ou du "Loup-Garou de Thiercelieux". Cependant, Throne of Lies fait preuve d'une profondeur de jeu bien plus grande, notamment grâce à la présence du role de Roi et de la possibilité pour l'équivalent des Mafias/loup-garous de convertir les autres joueurs dans le camp (selon bien sûr certaines limites), leur apportant un joueur au rôle différent selon son ancienne classe !
Les joueurs déjà morts ont la possibilité d'échanger entre eux, ainsi qu'avec le joueur "prêtre" s'il est présent/encore vivant, et ont de plus la possibilité de parier sur qui sera executé / mourra pendant la nuit, avec à la clé des pièces d'or permettant d'acheter des objets cosmétiques : cela rend le fait d'être mort beaucoup moins ennuyeux que ce à quoi on pourrait s'attendre.

En somme, il s'agit d'un jeu de déduction sociale d'une complexité profonde. Les développeurs sont indépendants et proches de leur communauté. Le jeu est en perpétuelle évolution et donc chacun doit en permanence apprendre à maîtriser les nouvelles mécaniques et ce qu'elles impliquent. Enfin, la courbe d'apprentissage est suffisamment bonne pour pouvoir s'en sortir au bout de quelques parties. Vous pouvez aussi compter sur la communauté très active du channel discord et sur des créateurs de contenu de qualité (Wahooz, PurpleyPete, Pipetron, ...) pour vous familiariser au jeu si vous avez peur de faire n'importequoi pendant vos première parties.
Petit + : Les développeurs ont d'ores-et-déjà annoncé qu'ils ne vendraient pas de DLC pour le jeu mais fourniraient du contenu gratuit.

Seul point négatif à mes yeux : à l'heure où j'écris ces lignes, la communauté est trop faible pour avoir une communauté française très présente, donc si vous ne maîtrisez pas l'anglais, vous risquez d'avoir du mal à trouver des parties auxquelles vous pourrez jouer, sachant que la base du jeu est tout de même d'échanger avec les autres joueurs.

I played this game ~10 hours straight and it was fun. But after this time i see many flaws of this game: 
- game is extremely confusing at the beginning. there is very little tutorial and players are thrown in the deep waters since start. there is a lot of nuances you have to learn (like reaper check or being aware of trollbox). you have to play like 10 games or so to get to know all the classes, and before that you basically have no idea what to do - a lot of new players do very questionable plays like random lynching and etc
- it is very similar to Mafia in terms of dying, sometimes you are killed turn 1 and you have no action to do until end, so you have to basically wait 15 minutes to know if you win or lose (yes, you can still win, because in the end the whole fraction wins)
- classes are very random in terms of usefulness, if you are prince or sheriff you have always a lot to do and you have a lot of information on other players, but if you are drunk, hunter or court wizard then you are practically useless the whole game. some classes are nicely balanced though like the princess

I certainly must agree it is very enjoyable to play as neutral with your own objective, but playing some useless BD classes or dying as first target is certainly not enjoyable. Also i played like 30 games and only one game was Cult game, so I think like there was a half of the game that was not really accessible to me. So basically I think i end my adventure with this game, it was quite fun, but too many drawbacks for me.


EDIT: ok i played a LOT of more of this game, and i regret a bit that Steam reviews system is binary - bad or good... i guess i change this to good review, but game still has SOME flaws.

35613645.review:
This has been a very fun game so far.

Pros:
- Relatively complex roles: up to four active abilities.
- Lots of different roles overall.
- King: powerful role visible to everyone from the start of the game, but with unknown allegiance. Just makes everything more interesting.
- Conversions: evil factions can convert people to their side. Increases complexity greatly as checked, trusted people can silently switch sides. Creates some really fun situations.
- Stability: the game has yet to crash, disconnect or otherwise break in 15 hours. Only bug i've seen was when a scorned won despite failing objective and committing suicide.
- Nice community so far.

Cons:
- Neutral roles often feel like odds are stacked against you, especially for neutral killers. Not a big con for me, but for some people it might be.
- Conversions: yes, despite being a pro earlier. Having to betray faction you tried your best to help can feel quite bad sometimes. Once again, not a big con in my opinion.

This review will be based off of Town of Salem, because I played that before this.

ToL has classes with 3-5 abilities, making it more engaging and fun. ToS has classes with 1 ability.
Let's take Priest from ToL and Retributionist from ToS. Retributionist can only revive one dead Town member. That's literally it. Priest is immune to one attack, can make another player immune for a night, can speak to the dead and revive a dead Blue Dragon member. Those four abilities make that class more engaging and more fun to play for players.

The King system influences the game greatly, while Town of Salem is a free-for-all with no deception involved.

The conversion system also influences the game, along with the 2 evil factions. You could have a confirmed Blue Dragon, and the next night they could be converted.

The developers are great people and will always answer your questions. Town of Salem's devs are greedy, rude people who won't ever answer your questions.

This game's community is rising in fame. We had 32 thousand people watching a Throne of Lies stream yesterday, and Town of Salem had 9 total viewers at the same time. :^)

TLDR: This game is better than Town of Salem, and it's worth the 10 bucks.

35595610.review:
So I won this game from a Youtuber (th_Pion). I had never played a social deduction game before and never thought I would. I've since been enjoiying it so much that I thought to give it my very first Steam review. At first I just stood around and watched and usually got picked off early for seeming suspicious because I had no idea what was going on (This happens but you will learn). 
Teamwork is key in this game, each role has abilities which provide information on a small piece of the puzzle and when combined with the information from other roles the teams can then begin to deduce who the odd or suspicious players are and silently kill them off at night or vote for their execution during day court.
the 4 class types (Offensive, Killer, Support, Investigative) must work together providing each other with their findings so that they can each carry out their roles succesfully eg. If an Investigative class discovers an enemy they must convey this info to a killer class to take action.
The catch comes in that you dont know the roles or classes of the other players and that you cant always trust the information you recieve, various abilities are able to skew the info and other players are rather partial to telling lies as the title of the game would suggest. Its your job to find ways to verify the info and convey it to the correct players in a way that they can trust you.
This is a very distilled description and there are many more dynamics in game which make for some tense situations. As rewarding as it is to weed out the Reaper and see them hung in court it is equally as dampening to your soul to see the teammates that you trusted so much turn out to be the bad guys. No other game that I have played can do that which makes me give it high ratings. Definitly worth a shot if it seems like your thing.

A lot of fun stuff messes around with the core mechanics of the game, like letting you make it look like someone said something they didn't, talking to dead players at night to find out what information they know, and so on.

The devs are constantly updating and patching (sometimes multiple times a day) and are very active on the Discord server, so it's a great time to get into this game.

35594909.review:
First off, I'm going to be looking at this from the perspective of someone coming to it from Town of Salem.

This game is amazing!!! Take everything good about Town of Salem, make it INCREDIBLY balanced, add a measly $10 to the price and you've got yourself a great, addictive game. In my last game as sheriff, we had 3 consecutive evil kings. Playing as sheriff I somehow managed to find 3 unseen (one was from my scout, which tells you if the person they're watching changes faction). I told the court to execute one of them and if they were innocent to execute me. They were an Assassin, so together with my hired mercenary and the Blue Dragons (BD), a.k.a. the good guys, I managed to execute all of the Unseen and the BD won the game against the odds. 

Some people say the evil factions always win but my first three games had the good factions win, it's up to luck and skill really. In terms of DLC and microtransactions,




Which is a welcome change from Town of Salem. The only in-game items are cosmetics (the weapons actually change how you execute someone in a trial, since it picks someone to execute a guilty character), which you buy from the in-game currency that you get just from winning games. You get 75 gold from a win and start with 500, which I think is reasonable considering the price of items ranging from 75-2000 gold. You can also make bets on who will die during the following day and night when you are dead, which is a welcome change from, well, not doing anything. 

The graphics have a nice cartoony feel to them, and are not hard on your computer. The art for the class portraits is very nice and immersive, which brings me to my next point, the in-game class info screen. This is a great feature, which describes in detail every class and its abilities. More on those later. Some other features that I really felt lacking in Town of Salem are seperate private notes for your eyes only, the ability to write way more on your will/journal, and finally, the amazing feature of not losing your writing if you press enter too early. 

Players from Town of Salem will know exactly what I mean. The game is reading off the list of people that died last night, and you're typing a great long message about how Deodat Lawson is clearly the Godfather, because he was immune to the vigilante but had claimed medium. Then you see the role of the last player who died and press enter. But your whole message disappears! This leads to having to copy it in case of this happening, which means losing whatever else you had copied beforehand. Well this is no longer an issue. Throne of Lies simply highlights your message if you can't send it.

Now, onto the roles (or classes as they are called) themselves. Every class is so much more interesting than in Town of Salem, with most having both day and night abilities, some even having more than one of each. At a minimum expect a class to have at least two or three abilities, with some like the King having about six iirc. None of the classes I have played as so far I have found boring in the slightest, with the least interesting being the Psychic, who is essentially a jailor without the ability to kill, but with two daytime abilities as well. Bare in mind I said the least interesting, whereas jailor is probably my favourite role in Town of Salem.

Finally, I'll talk about the playerbase. It's [i] amazing[/i]. Town of Salem is infamous for it's absolutely toxic playerbase, with a select few players who are actually nice to people and don't spam the chat/get triggered over a mistake/leave instantly. Well in Throne of Lies those select few are the norm. My first game everyone was helping me with basic controls and tips, and the discord (which I highly recommend) had lots of people giving me advice. One thing that is very helpful is to go to the wiki ( tol.wikia.com ) and have a look at the strategy section for the role you're playing. It's helped me out every game.

Also the music is good.

To sum up, I'd recommend this game not only to players of Town of Salem sick of the unbalanced roles, toxic community and microtransactions, but to any gamer in general. It's a great game that really captures the essence of the (slowly) growing Mafia-esque genre, and it's a joy to play. I'll probably be addicted soon enough.

P.S. I probably missed a whole topic, feel free to remind me of this in the comments.

35589821.review:
Throne of Lies is a great game and I really, really recommend you get it if you have ten dollars to spare.

Gameplay:
Throne of Lies is a social deduction game. There is so much to learn in this game, yet there is not a huge learning curve in the game. There are currently 41 classes in the game as I am writing this review all with their own unique night and day abilities. There is an easily accessible page of all of the classes and what they can do in and out of game. This is very useful if you are just getting into the game so you have limited questions. I prefer this game to Town of Salem as it required mroe thinking and more skill to get anywhere.

Graphics:
The graphics in this game are amazing. The game is coded in 3D, and the game just looks astonishing. During the day, all of the player models sit around the table. If they send a message in chat, their player model moves. If a player is voted to be executed for treason, an execution is shown to every player. There are some really awesome executions you can purchase in the shop (my personal favorite is Vortex of Corax, but it is 2K gold). You can also purchase skins for your avatar in the shop for various prices. More executions and skins are being worked on, but the ones in game look extremely nice. Also, most classes have their own night room, and the majority of these look extremely cool. My personal favorites are the Court Wizard, Psychic, and Butler rooms. The rooms are a very nice touch to this games - especially the Prince's cell. You actually change rooms to a jail cell if you're jailed by the Prince. That is great. You're not forced to look at a static image each night!

Community:
The community in this game is very active and, for the most part, decent. The Discord is extremely active and is a key part of the game. I highly suggest you get involved with the community. If you have any questions, just ask it in the general chat and you should get a response. Don't be shy, most of us don't bite! Oh, by the way, please do not draw penises on the death notes. We had death notes disabled for a while because of abundance of penises on the death notes. There is a report button now, though. I will admit, though, after release, the people in the game have been a bit more cancerous. That may just be because I'm not an easy person to get along with, though. But please, for the love of everyone, play the game well. If you're put on the stand, claim something. Don't just say that you're "good" or "i'm bd". That's not a sufficient defense most of the time. We do have a ton of YouTubers who play the game, and a recent surge in popularity was due to Lirik streaming the game (thanks Lirik!).

Developers:
This game's developers are miles better than Town of Salem's. This game gets frequent updates. 35560803.review:
== Updated October 9th ==

Confirmed buyer of two copies. One for myself and another for a friend's bday.

This is definitely an upgrade from the days of Mafia on Warcraft 3 custom games.  Typically games like these are ruined by the group atmosphere and trolls who seek to spoil the fun.  So far I've only encountered 1 troll and after he was reported was never seen again.  It seems the dev team takes reports seriously.  Something that has always gravitated me towards indie studios.

Gameplay is amazing, immersive and fun.  With a full 16-person game there's lots of opportunity to employ various strategies, and to change them over the course of the game as your class's goals shift.  Especially as neutral classes, the ability to work with others towards mutually beneficial ends that satisfy two goals so there can be multiple winners is a great caveat of Throne of Lies.

I'm reviewing this game with maybe 20-30 matches under my belt, just shy of 30 hours played.  At the time of writing, I have just won 5 games in a row.  First win of the series was as a Butler turned Servant as my predictions for trialing and executing the unseen were dead accurate.  With the trust of existing BlueDragon members, I used that to my advantage and ended up occupying most of them as my unseen allies picked them off 1 by 1 in the night while I called them to trial 1 by 1 during the day.  The very last game of the series was as an Alchemist, turned Neutral King in the lategame.  Protected by a Merc, I satisfied win conditions for both of us by not choosing sides too early, waiting until the herd was thinned, then siding with Unseen near the end to pick off remaining BlueDragon members.  The merc exhausted his Guard ability on me from Nights 3 through 6, just long enough to be able to choose a side to help win, where I rallied the Evil Majority, was converted to Neutral King and brought remaining BlueDragons to trial to close out the game.

For those of you looking for a mentally stimulating game you can play alone or with friends, definitely check out Throne of Lies!

Data:
Player population is about 400 active players on discord at the time of me writing this.  I've never had any trouble finding games.  Queue time is < 5 minutes round the clock.  Also a really active official discord server that you can find the info for ingame to connect with players and the game devs themselves to submit bugs and feedback.

Cons:
- Time between phases Night/Day and even Dead player reveals is too long in my opinion.  It feels like we're always hanging on to a scene a bit too long when someone is executed or when found dead in the morning.

Feedback:
- Dead chat history should reveal to all players upon game completion so players who survived can see what people who died were saying while the game went on.  Sometimes dead players will call out a really nice play or root for their favorite player still alive.  People will appreciate this if it's implemented :)
- Skin system is still quite tiny.  In my opinion there is too much emphasis put on executions/weapons and more love needs to be given to armor :)

35550740.review:
This game is more about CHAOS then about INFORMATION. 

Roles are very strong and many have multiple day or night abilities. This results in many neutral roles being very strong. While this seems balanced, it puts far more emphisis on avoiding the chaos of night actions rather that information and lying.

The game is called Throne of Lies...but I find that it should be called Court of Chaos as winning is more luck based then convincing others.

Conversion of town(blue dragon) to mafia (unseen or cult) is incredibly swingy as removing a crucial role.

Lynching a jester (fool) results in losing the fool lynch day, but also the next 2 days. This completely takes the power away from town and focuses it on night actions and kills.

The game is far more chaotic then a game of lies should be.

If you like powerful chaotic mafia, this game is tailor made for you. If you like informational deduction games, you may want to try a different game.

I will re review this in a couple weeks time and see if it becomes more informational based.



Edit AND REREVIEW: I do like the direction some of the changes have gone. While I still think the game is far more chaotic then a games advertised as being about information should be, I also like the direction many of the changes have worked.

I think the game could still be improved:

There is no stats in game? Easily the best thing about digital mediums for mafia is the ability to track stats. 

Achevements? Could easily have achievements based purely on winning as a faction or class to not compromise gameplay.

The amount of neutral classes that spawn add tons of chaos. 

It matters a ton about what faction the nightkill is from, and most of the evil factions have little to no way of checking. Again, chaos over information.

The low amount of information gained by evil is too low. Generally mafia works best with a informed coordinated minority versus a uncoordinated, uninformed majority. Instead we have a uninformed minority evil faction that blind converts people hoping to gain a little info along the way. In fact, the prince (always BD) and the king (can be anything, but hard to share said info unless town(BD).

Consistency of abilities and their balance changes every patch. The court wizard went from useless to one of the best roles for example.

The game is a great building block but it needs a lot of touch up work. However, because of the developers frequent patching and communication I have reversed my review.
35550740.developer_response:
Hi Tea -- We apologize you feel that way! Information is power in this game, or you perhaps have faced some new players (we only launched a week ago). We have monitored balance for over a year with community feedback and win rate statistics are showing extreme balance -- a feat that could not happen out of pure chaos.

If you are the King, your sole purpose is to socially manipulate everyone to stay alive. If you are not a Good king, you can use your ability to discover other factions, allowing you to negotiate either a truce or conspire with them.

Psychics can link minds with two people at a time, gathering information at a very rapid rate with the ability to anonymously tell others what you know.

The evils are all about information -- either projecting false information (to make them think a reaper/possessor is present, for example) or to get people into revealing their class to discover if they can be converted or not. If not, killed off.

It's all about info/timing.

This game is fun, its devs are willing to talk and listen as well as help out with advice or questions you may have, the community is fun and engaging and most like to roleplay it.

I would recommend this game for those that like to decieve others, roleplay, and want a community that is engaging as you can find this game to keep drawing you in. So here is some advice

Blue Dragon: Be attentive to the game, focus and watch for holes in some stories as all stories have at least one hole in it. Find an ally and group up to take out the Neutrals, the Unseen, and the Cult. Watch your back and dont get trigger happy with executes as some are just pure random, Never execute a prince claim nor don't Cold Steel a Prince claim, always guard the Prince who should never become King unless it is absolutely nesseciary.

Unseen: Work together and try and keep hidden from the Blue Dragon and Neutrals, Always pay attention to what you claim and how, there is only so much that can be used before your detected, Ive found sometimes its best to out an Unseen member that has a lot of heat and is already being suspected of being Unseen if it means you can remain hidden but that ONLY works for the mastermind as he is the most important role, dont get command happy either, you are a team so work together.

Neutrals: If your a Fool you need to be executed by the court, if your Scorned you need one of your targets executed by the court, if your alchemist you need to survive to the end of the game, if your Possessor you need to choose when to jump bodies when needed, and if you are Reaper you need to choose who to chill and who to reap, as some are immune but that can be by passed. If your Mercenary then you need to keep your contracter alive at all cost to win

Cult: Your job is similiar to the Unseen, convert, lie, kill and deceive the Blue Dragon and Neutrals, I've not managed to play as a Cult member yet so I cant really give any good tips on it

All in all for the roles, once you get the game spend some time learning them, use your brain and think of a plan but remember, No plan survives contact with the enemy

It's a game that is fun and as its still being worked on it can change as time goes on, ultimally you decide who will win this by your actions and words in the game, are you a Deceitful person or are you Truthful? are you a Roleplayer or are you a strickler for rules and game. its your choice but i find a combo is needed, always becareful of who you trust, as sometimes even a "proven" ally isnt always your friend or even your ally.

Decide which Faction wins and loses, Will it be the Blue Dragons? the Neutrals? the Cult? or the Unseen? join the community as well as its game and find out which faction you like the most and who will emerge the victory.

35520560.review:
This has been one week since the release for Throne of Lies,

Once you start the first round, you won't experience ever the same when deductions, the suspense, the conspiracies, daring murders and accusations become more common. Wait common? No, my friend...It's deeper than you can measure with. 

You arrive on Castle Adiart back either as member of Blue Dragon, Unseen or you are not afflicted with either side...sword for hire, court jester got tired of being belittled by the king, potion maker? What about the rumors of unnatural murderers across the realm...are you one of them?

You and fourteen other guests have arrived on throne room with the king in his presence until suddenly the castle doors have been sealed away, confused and perhaps afraid what's going on...your survival on the castle begins.

Throne of Lies is medieval fantasy-themed tabletop social deduction game as your goal is to eliminate the opposing faction or playing as neutral you have goal of your own, at day phase you discuss by the round table who is the trusted and traitor as well unsuspected players get affected by day abilities on this phase. During the night phase you decide to make actions such as the investigations, supporting your allies, discussing in secret or murdering the suspect, did you know your fellow healer class is actually now member of Unseen? How did that happen? The 'evil' factions are capable of converting 'good' faction classes, The Blue Dragon. Keep in mind that even few Blue Dragon classes have convert immunity and sometimes, you can earn that immunity when you get resurrected. Do you get roleblocked--I mean occupied too many times as you never get to kill someone? Don't worry! You become immune to occupations after three times in row whether you are killer or not, fewer classes have immunity to occupation as passives at start. During the dead phase, sometimes a Priest will able to talk with the dead as the graveyard is filling with ghosts that belong from the players are dead. You can also bet your gold who dies tonight during day phase and who get executed on trial during night phase. There are a lot of examples what can happen during these days and nights, who need plot twists of the game when this happens unexpecting right at front of your monitor

Throne of Lies offer you gameplay that no match is the old first match you have played before, same players with new names and equipment such as armor and weapons and randomly selected ambience soundtrack give you impression you are still standing by the throne room alive whilst unknown collaborators are plotting with someone's demise, it's in your imagination.

Since one week of the release I have enjoyed the brilliant victories and utter defeats, execellent soundtrack and gameplay play a role to this game, but so do my social deduction and manipulation that can change the tide of the game. The animations of your character hold foundation as you make gestures and open your mouth as you speak as well to react during the execution scenes, each weapon performs different execution styles. You have at night your own class-related bedrooms such as inside the church altar, the dungeon cell, alchemy room, your plate armor display on your room as Knight, magical runes and magical orbs as Psychic and Court Wizard and even throne made of bone and skeleton heads as Reaper and many more!

This is just the beginning. But not for the end.

35495997.review:
Played 3 games, died Night 1 in two of them. 10/10 would die again.

In all seriousness, this is a fairly compelling, very deduction focused Mafia/Werewolves style of game, similar to how Town of Salem plays. There's a "Good" faction (The Blue Dragons) and a "Bad" faction (The Unseen) (As well as a Cult faction but you won't run into them when starting) and the goals your trying to accomplish depend on your factions role. The Blue Dragons are trying to out all the Unseen and vice versa for the Unseen members. The twist is the Unseen know who members of their faction are at all times while the Blue Dragons are forced to figure it out through conversation and investigation. There's also a handful of Neutral roles thrown in to spice it up (some are trying to kill everyone else, some are trying to solely survive for example) There's also the King role, which starts Neutral but can be "Converted" onto the Unseen's side (Or the Cult's).

I did say "Converted" and that's another key feature of Throne of Lies, The Unseen start with a Mastermind and an Assassian, and the Mastermind can convert almost any role into an "evil" version of it, but there's always a limit of 3 members in the Unseen at any time. I use Town of Salem as a natural comparison for this style of game since it was the first Werewolves/Mafia game I got heavily interested in, but ToS requires a much smaller level of deductive reasoning required as it's really easy to whip up a mob mentality. In Throne of Lies, the role list of the game is completely hidden, and the only roles that are always there are King, Prince, (and for games with Unseen) Mastermind, and Assassain. Not knowing what could possibly exist means that there's more room for doubt when it comes to potential for claiming, and you have to be almost certain you know the person you're going to send to trial is guilty or not.

Although I haven't "Played" much of Throne of Lies at the time of writing this (That joke at the top wasn't just a joke.) I still see the potential this game has to offer for people who enjoy investigative deception style games like this or ToS, and if you've played ToS before you'd feel right at home with it. And although the community for it is small right now (It DID just launch) it's a very committed one who are willing to help new players along at learning the game. Because if you haven't played something like this before, there is a bit of a learning curve, and I have no idea how the Cult roles will play differently to the Unseen when I get a chance to play games with those enabled. My one concern is just the community size is small and it can take a while for games to start (I had a 10 minute queue time for my third game), so it isn't a sort of "Pick up and play" Like how ToS would be. But that's something that can be fixed with time and more players (The game supports a Minimum of 8 Players and a Max of 16, which is just the right amount for this type of game). I look forward to jumping back in to more sessions of this with my friends and the loyal group of players this game has already accrued, and I think if you enjoy a good session of Mafia/Werewolves this is your style of game.

35463115.review:
[h1] Throne of Lies is FAR SUPERIOR to Town of Salem[/h1]

The majority of people who will come reading these reviews will probably be those who have experience with town of salem and epicmafia but are still on the fence if Throne of lies is worth 10 bucks for the same experience.

Let me start off this review by making the audacious claim that Throne of Lies is a much more complex, engaging, and entertaining game than Town of Salem will ever be. If you have 9 dollars to spare, [b]YOU SHOULD BUY THRONE OF LIES[/b] and stop wasting your time with town of salem. Here is why.

1.[b]Role Complexity[/b]- Every single role has 3-4 different abilities as opposed to town of salem where each role has 1 ability. Why does this matter? Every single player has the capability to win the game on their own with deception and skill. Town of Salem can be so frustrating where you feel powerless as a spy in a game with no whispers, or as lookout with no results. Even the neutral roles contains so many abilities. These extra abilities add much more thinking to the game. You aren't just a survivor who vests 4 times in this game. The alchemist(survivor equivalent of throne of lies) who also just has to survive till the end of the game, has 2 kill potions, 3 vests, and infinite healing capability. You have to really think who should I heal and keep alive? Should I kill the bastard who is accusing me of being unseen? Should I vest(stone-skin potion) since I'm being accused tonight. The point is you have to actually think when you use your ablitites, it isn't just monotonous, clicking one button every night. With this much power, any player can win with skill, you just have to play smart and you will be rewarded. In town of salem, survivors do literally the same thing every game. put 4 vests and pray town won't execute you and mafia won't kill you, lol. The alchemist is just 1 example of an improved role from town of salem. The entire game can be considered an improvement from town of salem which fixes every problem that game had.

2.[b]Shorter Timers[/b]- God bless these devs for implementing shorter timers. In town of Salem, the timers are unbearably long once you learn the game. There is no need for so much time to do 1 generic ability at night or 5 entire minutes to execute a confirmed baddie. When the game drags out and nothing happens, the game feels stale fast, town of salem has had this problem for a while, If you are coming from town of salem, you will really love the shorter timers in throne of lies. The game feels fast-paced.

3. [b]The King[/b] - The King is just another element added to the game that increases the complexity of the game. He can be good, neutral or evil. You really can't tell right away, but he holds a lot of voting and executing power, as well as the ability to guard himself and other players and can even investigate others. There is 1 king in every single game.
The evil guys, the neutral players, and the good guys don't know the king's faction. Every single players has to deduce the king's faction through his actions/attitude in the game. The king is a very powerful player who can tip the game to either side if he survives till the end. Killing or keeping him alive makes or breaks the game for your faction. What does this mean? Not only do you have to kill everyone in the opposing faction and do your best to complete your role's objective, you have to keep tabs on the king!

4. [b]No Metagaming[/b] - The most frustrating thing for me in town of salem was being asked to post my role's objective in jail to the jailor. That isn't how the game is intended to be played. I'm not expected to post my role's objective to you. You are expected to find my role with clues and anaylsis, not by worthless metagaming lul. Another example is spychecking spies, adding names in will for disguisor, random voting when blackmailed, the list just goes on and on. Town of Salem is riddled with meta gaming which ruins the game immensely.
In Throne of lies, I have not seen any cases of metagaming which ruin the game for me. The game is really well designed and makes it extremely difficult to do so. You will really appreciate that this game is won more so with analysis than ridiculous cheating.

5. [b]Community[/b] - Another huge point for Town of Salem players. Town of Salem is a FREE game. That means any child on the internet can make an account and plague your games. Especially since Town of Salem is a team-reliant game where half the town roles only have 1 ability and they must communicate to get anything done. This make the game UNBEARABLY frustrating and can honestly convert level-headed players to toxic players in no time at all.
Throne of Lies has a 9 dollar paywall to enter the game. 9 dollars is not much all, but it will block those damned little kids out. The current Throne of Lies community consists of olders players who have played town of salem and epicmafia long ago, or are just trying something new. The players are welcoming and patient. Everyone is learning! Toxicity is limited in this game simply because the game is designed so much better. Better players will win their games single-handedly, they aren't reliant on the team since every player's role has so much power.

6. [b]Devs and Updates[/b] - I've only played for a couple weeks and I've already noticed so many constant large game-changing updates and buxfixes. It is very apparent that the devs are passioniate about making the game the best they can. They put the game at just 9 dollars to give you constant updates and constant accessability. I've also noticed there is no stupidly pointless dlc. All the skins and weapons can be bought with in-game currency which is SO much easier to gain than in Town of Salem. In Town of salem, you have to pay an absurd amount for executions, skins, pets, etc. They are milking players for all they got. Especially when their game has remained static it amazes me that they can still do this. The throne of lies developers could have doubled the price of the game, they could have added pointless dlc, they could have turned this entire game into a cash grab, but they didnt.

Why did I make this review? So that Throne of Lies can get the larger player base it deserves.
