In my opinion, from every respect, this game is a definite next step from Town Of Salem. I give it my hearty reccomendatiom.

The mechanics are designed to allow every class to have many uses and abilities, discussion times are longer allowing much more interplay and scumreading than ToS allows, and most importantly the devs have actually managed to make a game in where conversion is not completely asinine.

Think the Vampires were a bad idea? You're right.

But here the conversion is woven heavily into the mechanics of the game, it feels natural and actually makes sense. Only one class (The Prince) allows you to truly be confirmed Blue Dragon, all the others can be converted at any time. You can't trust anyone, and that's great.

Not only that, but the abilities that aren't just mutliple ToS roles combined into one are genius. Discover them for youself, you'll be pleasently surprised.

And most importantly, the community is completely non-cancer. I'm being honest, the complexity of the game is it's greatest asset, allowing for complex strategy, and it drives off bad players.

Pros:
-Complex roless allow interplay and strategy to rule.
-Many umnentioned gameplay improvements from other Mafia games allow for a good experience.
-Keeps aspects from ToS allowing people to get into it. The overall concept is intuitive and easy.

Cons:
-May be too complex for some players
-The game is still rather new, so you may struggle to get a game depending on your timezone.

*Credits to forum user Sketch for giving me my alpha/beta key. You have my thanks.*

35403350.review:
This game is TONS of fun and highly addictive. It has an (admittedly) steep learning curve, but if you stick with it and begin to really learn the finer mechanics of the game, what you will find is a clever and well thought out experience that will keep you on your toes every round you play.

The large number of available classes - some of which have their own unique win conditions - will always keep you second guessing everyone's motives and cross checking their claims. It's always thrilling to discover the traitors among you by connecting the dots and weeding out their lies. Perhaps most importantly, the game remains entertaining even when you fail to do so. It is just as entertaining to outplay your foes as it is to be outplayed by them, and should you yourself perish along the way, it's fun to comment on the happenings of the game with the other dead from beyond the grave.

If you've played games such as Town of Salem, you should know what to expect here. If you are like me and have not ever played a game quite like this one before, though - give it a chance. Once you learn what's going on and get a feel for the game, you'll not want to put it down.

The promise of future updates adding in new roles and perhaps new factions can only serve to make the game even more entertaining in the future. All in all - well worth a buy at full price, but a definite buy if ever on sale.

35310262.review:
Throne of Lies is a Secret Identiy Multiplayer Social Deduction Game.
It has similar core mechanics as games like Werewolf, Mafia, Town of Salem, Secret Hitler, The Resistance and the like. The game is (similar to The Resistance) very focused on it's mechanics: It has a lot of special abilities flying around and a lot of possibilities to get hard facts (or at least very solid hints) as opposed to almost pure guesswork (as in say Werewolf). This is mainly due to two core mechanics:
1. If you die you role (and faction) gets revealed to everyone.
2. You have a journal in which you can take notes. If you die, the journal will be revealed to everyone.
If you are one of the investigator classes of the Blue Dragons (the "good" faction) for example, your best bet is to write as much information down as you could gather. When you get killed your allies will get all your notes + 100% confirmation that you are not lying (due to the role reveal).
The gameplay mechanics itself are pretty solid. There are a lot of interesting abilities and the over 40 roles seem to be balanced quite nicely as well. Unfortunately the plurality of roles and abilities also means that the learning curve is ridiculously steep.
The biggest downside to this game however is it's terrible UI. There is only one hotkey in the whole game (for opening the help screen). Windows (like the journal) cannot even be closed with the esc key.

More Details + Gameplay: https://gaming.youtube.com/watch?v=MgdMxs2JcQE

35305932.review:
My best Throne of Lies moment to date:

I was the Evil faction's Mastermind..  I needed to devise a plausible cover for my character incase I was accused of anything.  From the beginning, I had the perfect plan.  Having gotten the hang of the character roles, I decided to write an entire journal posing as "The Sheriff," investigating players and lamenting when the Evil scoundrels had slipped through my fingers.  Then, they would all trust me.  All the while I'm sending my minions out to kill, kill kill.

But there was a fly in the ointment.  Another player outed themselves as the real Sheriff and said he had some info on us..  Suddenly one of my loyal scoundrels was up on the stand for treason!  I managed to throw in a red herring in his defense, just enough to make the Good faction doubt their decision.  He was saved.

That night, the Prince imprisoned me.  If I slipped up here, the Prince would execute me right there in my cell.  "What's your role?" he asked."  "Sheriff," I said. "The other Sheriff is lying."  "Show me your Journal," commanded the Prince.  At last, the moment I'd been waiting for.  A simple copy and paste and he'd have my bogus Journal as evidence.

It worked.  I'd convinced him.  I was off the hook, and operating under the guise of one of the most valuable Good faction roles, the Sheriff, in the eyes of the most dangerous Good faction player, the Prince.

Only one problem.  While I was in the dungeon, my Assassin had gotten an itchy trigger finger and murdered the real Sheriff that night.  "Thomas Carew has died.  Thomas Carew was a (Sheriff)."  Among his public Journal notes: "Investigate #9.  9 is Unseen (Evil)!"  ..Whoops.

The Prince jailed me that night.  "Sup Prince?" I asked.  No reply.  I was executed in the morning.

10/10, would botch a Royal conspiracy again.

35304645.review:
I have been following this game for a while, and it has really changed for the better. Abilities were removed which didn’t work, new classes were added, classes were made more fun. These Devs are already more competent than BlankMediaGames (Town of Salem’s developers)
One little thing I feel like I need to point out is that every player gets their own room at night. While this may seem like a little thing, it really improves on my immersion, especially compared to Town of Salem’s night which just makes the screen darker. When you are part of the cult or Unseen, you all meet together around a table, which really helps me feel like I am plotting against the Blue Dragons (The town).

Classes
The abilities are a hell of a lot more fun than Town of Salem. One comparison is the Sheriff. Town of Salem allows the player to see if someone is mafia, werewolf or a serial killer. Throne of lie’s version allows you to check if they are Unseen (Throne of Lie’s version of mafia) and allows you to put a scout on the player, telling you if they are converted. If you yourself get converted, you get new abilities. The sheriff, for example, becomes the Marshal who can listen into the Prince (Throne of Lie’s Jailor) at night, giving you potential info, see who the Prince jails, and read other player’s wills at night, turning the sheriff into an information powerhouse. Another example is the Alchemist, who is the Survivor of Throne of Lies, having the only objective to survive. In Town of Salem all the Survivor can do is protect themselves at night 4 times. In Throne of Lies the Alchemist can heal players almost like a doctor would, and kill players themselves, allowing you to choose if you want to act as a protector or killer.

Unseen - Converting
So, besides 100x better classes, you have the convert feature. I absolutely HATE being Mafia in Town of Salem. They are just “Use this ability or not”, that’s it. But in Throne of Lies you start off with the Mastermind and Assassin (Godfather and Mafioso). The Mastermind can convert players into the Unseen, giving them new, more evil abilities, like how Vampires work in Town of Salem. This creates a constant distrust between players, which can be taken advantage of by the Unseen.

The King
The king is a player whose role is confirmed to the rest of the court. His faction however, is not. He gets double votes, a final say on executions, an investigative ability and a protective ability. Most of the Blue Dragon (The town) can use negative abilities on him, so the only way for them to kill him is by voting him up, while none of the Unseen will want to kill a potential extra ally until they are certain.

The Bad
The game isn’t perfect. The graphics, especially the people, look bad, the UI is bad and the animations are bad. The game also severely lacks a lot of sounds like message sounds.

Overall I would recommend if you enjoy Town of Salem or Mafia. The major thing which was lacking when this was in beta was the lack of players (which should hopefully be fixed now).

35303982.review:
A bootleg-tier product. I've been monitoring the developer's progress on this for about half a year and here is my conclusion. This is clearly a drunken-rage-induced product based on misleading assumptions and vastly incorrect conclusions about a competitor game, which resulted in both this and snarky dialogue aimed at said competitor game littered with false equivalency and plain, observable incorrectness.

As for the gameplay, there was some semblance of effort put into this, but you can see that it's not all quite there. For example, the lobbying and chat functionalities are littered with uncaught bugs (what was the point of the one year early access again?). However, the 16th player does correctly fuck off as intended as the 16th player in any game is always a complete tosspot and you do not want them, so that's a bonus there. Unless that was broken since I last played.

Now specifically, the game is fundamentally different to games like Mafia and Werewolf, where information is even more important than your life, which you just lost, so nevermind trying to actually do anything. Free loss! Yay!

You can have some, too:

   |     ||
   ||    |_

It is absolutely imperative that you claim to be a Prince. Always. Or at least claim to be The Artist Formerly Known As Prince, which might get you killed immediately since he's already dead (nani?!).

This game also contains something called "Laws of Aviation," which prevents bees from being able to fly, because it dictates that their wings are improperly sized for the task of producing the required downforce to lift them off of the ground, which is an exceptionally bad decision, considering the fatal effect this has on the medieval food chain.

The concept is fine, it could just use some better delivery.

Overall, it's a pretty rage-inducing game, so if you're out of salt I would definitely recommend it. If you want to enjoy a game, hard fucking luck.

10/10

ToL is a fantastic 3D social deduction game.
It has lots of classes and some have both day and night abilities. 
The music is great and you can draw your own deathnotes, which adds lots of extra enjoyment for me personally.
The developers are hard working and are extremely kind and will help you out the best they can if you are experiencing any problems.

[h1]Helpful things if an issue occures[/h1]
If you have an older computer and your game crashes try disabling the 
camera rotation which can be found in settings and it might be a good idea to set the graphics lower.
If you find a bug or the game crashes you can report it here on their discord: https://discord.gg/gvNbRSB
On the discord there is also a matchmaking section so you can go there and see if there is a game running or about to start.  You can also chat with the community.  The community is quite helpful so if you have any questions about how to do things don't hesitate to ask. 

Throne of Lies is an absolute must have if you enjoy the social deduction genre and I look forward to what Imperium42 does in the future. 
But for now It's time for you to claim the [b]Throne[/b]

39521560.review:
At its current state this game is passable and I'd even call it fun. The development team is obviously fresh but they've put together a decent and cohesive experience. I can only hope the success they've experienced will be funneled into further development. They doubtlessly have a road-map but I feel a single feature should take precedent over all but game breaking bugs. That is to say:  
  
This game is in desperate need of a simple in-game VOIP mic, whereby only a single player can talk at a time for certain moments of gameplay. The biggest mechanical problem with this game lacks before its tabletop counterparts is the humanity of the bluff that makes the mafia/werewolf genre fun. That is to say, the part where you try to figure out if someone is lying! Right now this consists of cut/pasting from the log book while other players determine if this stacks up to what happened throughout the game. This is not the, "fun" part of the mechanic but rather the logic side of a coin, the other side of which is human. 

When defending themselves the player should make their case to the group verbally, using their log book only for personal reference. This single-person mic mechanic will radically redefine the nature of the game to its human roots. Making the experience more fun and spontaneous, like the table top version. The king can address his vassals, the accuser make their case, the accused defend themselves, while the graveyard is a free-for-all of gibbering, memes, and jokes. 

Do it, devs. You know I'm right.

39516664.review:
This game made me lose my faith in humanity. Then I got it back.
And then lost it again. Truly a rollercoaster of emotions with every game I took part in. 

One thing that is awesome with this masterpiece of a betrayal simulator is that you can choose any name you want when entering a game! (Not really though, a lot of words are not accepted) Well, it doesn't really matter since everybody calls themselves by their player numbers, making it even harder to understand some of the nonsense people can say at times, such as "14 BD Check - NS" (some of these can even have multiple meanings, such as "NK" that can be used both for "Neutral King" and "Neutral Killer").

But it's all worth it in the end, because right after you finally start to understand how this game and the roles work by reading the entire manual, playing the tutorial, and then reading countless of outdated meme-filled guides, you will finally be able to enter your very first game, and discover that more often that you might be led to believe, you're most likely going to be dead on the first night, and spend the rest of the game hoping for something to happen, or just quit and look for another game where it'll happen again.

As for when you're finally going to play without dying from the get-go, you'll quickly find out how awesome (or boring) this game can really be. I absolutely do not regret buying it, and I don't even regret having to spend hours reading guides to learn how to play better. If you like plot twists, betraying your friends, and Town of Salem, you're definitely going to have a lot of fun on this one, trust me.

7.5/10. Gotta love some backstabbing.

P.S - Pretty dissapointed in the lack of roleplaying though, most people will call you a nerd if and when you decide to do it

39574471.review:
I don't generally write reviews for games, but this game is great. It's a more polished, better balanced, less cluster-ey rendition of the classic mafia game than Town Of Salem. The game has some areas where it lacks polish, and balance is a constant struggle, but it does well, especially compared to similar entries to the genre of social deduction. The game's asking price of $10 is admittedly high for the casual player, but as of writing this review, I have played 28 hours in 3 days, and feel that it was worth every cent. I follow the $1/hour rule of thumb, and this game pays itself off gloriously. 

The game can be a bit overwhelming at first, especially given the constantly changing meta one would expect. However, there are lots of wonderful streamers who stream this game constantly, and are more than happy to answer questions. The game also produces some wonderful memes (10 is always evil!), and is all around very solid. Cosmetics are fairly cheap to get, and are just that: cosmetic. There are no microtransactions, and you earn gold, even on a defeat. Plus, to get more (if you care) you can bet on who you think will die or be executed, earning yourself a nice bonus if you are correct.

39547878.review:
Noobie Review. 
From my point of view, this game has been very engaging from day 1. I have clocked in many hours since buying the game and I have never regretted this purchase. Here's some of the reasons why.

-Simple to go in, but complex enough to keep playing.
Sure, it is hard for a person to go in, but when you grasped the basics, this game becomes really fun to play. You will never know what will happen, or the person who holds the information. Once people get used to information, as this is a multiplayer game, each match you go into is a differrent experience.

-Great Community! 
When I went in, the game was really smooth, even for new players it was really friendly. Sure there are patches along the way but generally everyone is really accomodating towards each other. The people in the Discord also help out a lot!

-Developers that Interact.
These developers are something I would really like in other games, as they are ones that are very active and communicate a lot with us players. Most of our suggestions, they do reply and indicate that they are listening, even when they are busy with their work. They have also released their own plans for the game, even if it was "just a little bit of their plans", this shows that they have been listening to us. They let us know of what they plan for the game, this I very much appreciate.

-Moderators that do WORK
There is a report system to keep the community system clean, and that this report system is very effective. The moderators themselves do manage each report personally and decide on the severity of the situation. However, this is not the reason why I like it. The reason that I like this for is because they do punish for salt/revenge reports. This is something I believe many other multiplayer games should have, These moderators keep the game clean and therefore keep the community nice.

Overall, I would recommend this. It may be a little difficult to get into, I would suggest going to watch videos or streamers before entering into the world of Throne of Lies
